First thing first we ordered mojitos which were delicious, smooth and hit the spot as we were chatting away. Our server apologized for the initial treatment of the pointing situation, very aplogetic to us. The food: ceviche de pecsado (rojo) y camaron, I could taste the feshness with each bite. The red onions with lemon simplicity at its best paired well with mojitos. We also ordered arroz con mariscos just yum; rice,shrimp and mussels cooked perfectly. Chicharron de pollo, my goodness so good cooked perfectly and enjoyed ever bite. Dessert mango gellato with starwberry and mango dressing just superb. Great experience and although it was just two of them, very aplogetic but able to serve us professionally without crazy wait time.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I am giving it two stars because I did not pay. Not only was service so-so you might want to CALL to see if they actually have what you want. 
They were out at 730pm of Red snapper ceviche and the octopus.
author: JD J.

description:
It's been a long time since I was at Limon, and definitely not since they changed the menu to the rotisserie style.  While I enjoyed the food we had, as well as the wine we selected, I'm not sure that the Mission needs two Limon Rotisseries, since the original is still on S. Van Ness.  I do miss the finer dining attributes that the original Limon offered.  But I guess the down economy has forced many places to reformat to survive.

My only gripe with the experience this past week was that there were 3 items that were offered on the menu that were not actually available.  I wouldn't normally comment on this, but when it comes to 3, including a dish that the server had talked up, then it does tend to dampen the experience.  Two were actually wines: we had ordered one of the malbecs only for the server to come back and tell us they were out of that one.  Back down to the cellar he went for our second malbec choosing, and when he returned we noted (not him, but us) that it was not the same vintage as listed on the menu.  Generally not a good thing for wine since each year brings a very different experience.  As it turned out, the one we had was pretty good.  And lastly, the server talked up a dish, so we ordered it; he came back to tell us they had sold out.  This last one is probably the most frustrating as the kitchen and the floor staff should communicate better on such things.  We survived, but it's just not a great experience and that's what going out to eat is all about - the experience.

I'd definitely go back, although the original Limon Rotisserie is closer to me so I'll likely go to that one.  

I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt on my stars.  I would have chosen 3.5 if I could.
author: Scott L.

description:
Went here on a Monday.  They seemed really busy, which I guess is good for them. Not so good for me though.  The place was REALLY loud.  I had to shout to my girlfriend across the table.  Our initial order, (they deliver items as soon as they are prepared) the Jalea, was good, the other four items were very salty.  

I guess that would have been okay except for the fact that we had that experience where the people that sat AFTER us were getting their food BEFORE us - and some of their items were exactly what we had ordered. That leads to the cascade - as I call it - of criticism.  

So our waiter was a bit much. He seemed proud of his menu, but a little too much so; as if to say, "Why are you bothering me with these questions about my lovely menu?"

The couple next to us returned an item that they felt had been over salted, so we knew it wasn't just our overly critical foodishista natures. Most probably it was just a heavy handed cook that night. 

In fact, I recommend you give them a chance.  I probably will again.  I am thinking that they just had a rough night.
author: Mike P.

description: I LOVE this restaurant!!!! We ordered the ceviche, half chicken, mac and cheese, polenta fries, rice and steak. I am surprised at how good the chicken tasted!! It was full of flavor, juicy and moist. I was skeptical at first since I usually don't like to order chicken. The ceviche was bomb da com!! It was very fresh. The best part was the price. Its not expensive! Too bad it is always crowded :(
author: Rosanna T.

description:
Salt overload.

This restaurant came highly recommended...

However, we could not get past the severe saltiness of the Seco de Cordero (braised lamb shank) and Lomo Saltado (tossed sirloin)....

...maybe it was a bad night.
author: Tricia D.

description: The food is really good and tasty. Menu is also a bit confusing if your not familiar with Peruvian food.  Service can get slow when it's crowded which can get frustrating as well.
author: Seven R.

description:
I went to dinner there a few nights ago... the server overcharged my card by $60 putting my bill from $40 to $100!!!! The only reason I found out was because my account said it was overdrawn (I'm a very poor grad student) :/
Luckily, I kept my receipt and the charge will be reversed. Jesus M (our server) was trying to commit fraud. The food was fine but I will absolutely never be back there again!! Shady!!!
author: Alissa P.

description:
We have Sunday night reservations here for 7:00pm. I arrive with my friend 5 minutes after 7 and we are the last to arrive in our party. Our party is seated in the lounge area and we are waiting and chatting and really having a good time of it.I was not keeping track at the time though it seemed like 30 or 40 minutes after we arrived that they ask if we would like drinks. I order the soju sour -- it is tasty. 

This is when I start noticing the time. About an hour after our reservations, the manager comes out and says that some folks had to be seated. We ask to be served food and they let us sit at the kiddie table to order food. We order food and plead for water. About 5 minutes later, a woman comes and explains that they are "working on water" for us. Five minutes after that we get water. The place is packed and I can understand being strained on staff. 70 minutes between arrival and water is absurd. We see the waitress one more time before our food arrives so she can take another drink order which I decline though others get wine and sangria.

At 8:50, 50 full minutes after ordering our food, it finally arrives. At this point, the place is mostly empty so you would think the help staff would be more attentive. No, the manager is in the back talking to what appears to be one of the cooks as they chat near the entrance to the kitchen.

Everyone dives into their food. All conversation stopped for at least 10 minutes as the hungriest people in that venue begin to gorge. I had the chicken and peppers with mac & cheese while my friend had the snapper. We shared. The snapper was ok though the dipping sauce was excellent. The pepper/mushroom mix with the chicken was very good. The chicken was tasty though nothing special. It tasted like chicken. The mac and cheese was excellent.

We start enjoying ourselves at this point since our minds have been taken off of the hunger pangs. We are all laughing and having a good time. Maybe too good because though the waitress did not appear to have any other customers and the hostess had few new heads appear in the door, we could not get their attention or the bill. We are supposed to go the the orbit room to meet other friends at 9:00 and it this point it is 9:30. Finally, we get the bill, pay way too much money for the abuse we've been served by the staff, and excuse ourselves from the restaurant after rejecting their offer of some kind of cake.

My advice: order the mac & cheese to go over the phone. Flip a coin. Heads you go get it, Tails you make them eat it.
author: Phoenix T.

description:
Korufied. Saucy. Modern. 

Korufied. 
A redesigned Peruvian-American fusion chosen based on ingredients. The once overlooked Mission spots now attracts yuppies and foodies alike. 

Saucy. 
Pupusa - crispy pork pupsa with mustard tangy yet dangling sweet sauce scores a big hit. 

Pork Ribs - my personal favorite. Dry yet bones falling off the bone. Muaw. 

Cerviche flights - Saucy. red snapper Miso mingles with my oral palette. 
All enticing to the senses. 

Modern - Decor moderne with a psychedelic touch. 

Surprise - purple-corn sparkling drink quenches my fevering thirst.
author: Jack C.

description: Great place to take a girl on a date. I enjoy sharing smaller plates of well proportioned foods & savor while having a drink. I thought the service was great & we were seated near the window, so it was a nice experience.
author: Lily R.

description: Very loud. Food was ok, but nothing too extraordinary. Drinks were good tho
author: Shirin E.

description:
I'm not quite sure what all the fuss is about, but Limon is a bit lackluster for my tastes.  The food is livable and the service discouraging (twenty minutes between ordering a cocktail and actually getting it?  F'reals??), but they're somehow packin' 'em in.  

You think Peruvian food, you think an extravaganza of South American flavors, not palate-deflating dishes.  And while our waiter was a friendly (and quite cute) fellow, he couldn't seem to get our orders right.  We had to repeat two or three orders, and follow up on drink requests.  I get that they were busy, but for Pete's sake, this isn't a new restaurant.

Disappointing.
author: shojua p.

description:
Good place to eat. You feel full, but the food is definitely not heavy.

Ceviches and fried chicken are exceptional.

Lomo Saltado is decent- nothing extraordinary.
author: Patrick P.

description:
Came for lunch today and had the Limon pescado. Flippin delicious. mmm so tasty. It was three little pieces of white fish, sauteed with a little crisp to it over a bed of spinach, which was over a bed of sliced potatoes. Can you say yum?! It was amazing.

Lunch hour seemed to get busier around 1:30. Service was great!
author: Joy A.

description:
So the staff was super attentive--a lil' too much if you ask me. They were right there to take your dishes away as soon as you finished. This service is only nice in a timely manner; otherwise, it just feels like they were rushing you out! It wasn't super busy for them to do that so my sister and I were annoyed. I was hoping to catch up with her since I just picked her up from the airport and this seemed like the place to do it--seing that the ambiance gave out that vibe anyway. 

The food could have made up for it IF the waiter didn't mess up on half of our order. Everything was good but not amazing and b/c of the mistakes, it was damper in our review.

But the mango mojito was good...
author: Mary D.

description:
Solid, but I wasn't blown away.  Given all the hype, I was expecting a bit more.  I can say, however, that I am excited.... thrilled that they will be opening up a place in the Bayview.  

Not sure what other details I need to give though, since the other 1000 reviewers have already said it.
author: Naka H.

description: DO NOT sit upstairs on the table where you are right under the hot track lights... man you sweat like your food under the heat lamp... so glad the servers moved us to somewhere more comfy and less hot. We started off with oyster shooters and that was pretty good. The ceviche limon and camarones were ok. The beefsteak aka lomo saltado was pretty good, real real good. The best part of the night was the desserts that the bf ordered... he ordered all the desserts hahahaha for us party of 5. The tres leches was not all that... i do remember a sorbet that was reaaally good... the rest were meh. I do not recommend buying mixed drinks because it just tastes like juice... i understand its not a full bar but man we just paid for expensive juice mojitos hahahahaha.. the place does get pretty loud since everyone is next to eachother. It was a fun experience but i dont think ill come back.
author: Mary Ann B.

description:
The worker who answered the phone asked me if he was being "Punk'd" when I changed my reservation, which was a little dramatic of him.  ( I had changed my RSVP from 9pm to 5pm because it fit my itinerary better).  

Ordered the Cebiche Limon, which was good.  The only thing that was unusual was the bonus yam that was included in it. ( I love yams, so no complaint from me...but still a bit odd)  
The whole red snapper was more visually appealing than savory.  Their sangria was one of the better tasting I've had in the city. 

Great decor and an extremely polite waiter.  The quality of food is definitely worth the prices charged.

Parking wasn't easy peasy, but we were able to utilized the parking garage which was only a short walk away.
author: Agent X.

description:
5 stars. Even tho our waiter was a slow and a lil rude and our hostess was very inhospitable and refused to seat us at our table for an awkward 5 mins because the rest of our party had not arrived yet. Seriously, we just stood their and traded barbed stares with her before she relented and seated us.  

Why such forgiveness? Because two dishes were out of this world.

One, the truffle mac and cheese. Just phenomenal. I have had lots of mac and cheese but this was incredible. You really could lightly taste the truffle oil, and the mix of flavors perfectly balanced and just absolutely incredible. It was the most perfect bowl of mac and cheese I have ever had. Just perfectly amazing. If you don't like this, then you don't like food. 

The next dish? Limito saltado. My.....dear......god. This was probably one of the best brunch dishes I have ever had. It just makes me skirm a little thinking about it and I just want more. It is two over easy eggs over steak, French fries, onions, and covered in some soy sauce. I know that sounds good, but it really doesn't do it justice about how good it is. The steak is perfectly seasoned and cooked for this dish and the flavor of it and the sauce is just phenomenally delicious. And then mix in the egg with a the onions and GAH! Just mouthwatering! The flavor of all theses just mix in such an overpowering delicious way that I really didn't want each bite to end, never mind the actual meal. It was just amazing. Simply outstanding and phenomenal. So good in fact, that I didn't use the word phenomenal enough in this review, so I will end this review by saying it a few more times,  phenomenal phenomenal phenomenal.


Oh, our table was on the 2nd floor over looking the whole place. Pretty neat!
author: Tom O.

description:
First time I visited: terrible service, mediocre dishes.

Second time around: what a difference. Total 180 degrees.

I have to give kudos to Limon SF's Twitter team (handled by Laurina) who reached out to me on Twitter after I gave them a less than stellar review on Yelp. She wanted me to give Limon a second chance, and offered me a gift certificate to do so. There's not very many restuaurants that take the time to try and win over a dissatisfied customer, but Limon SF did.

On our second visit, we had a different waiter, and I decided to order different dishes in order to give the restaurant a fresh chance. 

This time when I asked to start off with the sweet potato fries, they arrived before our main dishes as I had asked. I ordered the Limon Shooter (which was basically a sampler of the ceviche) along with a side of coconut fried rice, and the Pollo Merengue.

WOW. Incredible. The ceviche was especially delicious, probably the best ceviche I've had in the city (and I've had a lot of ceviche). My boyfriend ordered the Quinotto de Vegetales (basically a Vegetable Quinot), which was pretty darn perfect I must admit.

Now, what did we order the first time around? I ordered the Lomo Saltado and he ordered the Veggie omelette. I was disappointed with their Lomo, but was told upon our second visit that they had heard me loud and clear: the lomo wasn't juicy enough and they had made it juicier. I'm impressed they even cared to be honest. His veggie omelette, while good, wasn't great.

So, my suggestion: stick to the cevhiche (incredible), and their other dishes. Give their lomo saltado a shot (apparently, they're improved it), but don't go for the omelette dishes.

Ultimately, though, my second visit to the restaurant was the total opposite of my first visit. I recommend the restaurant...just don't go with the omelettes. It doesn't accurately reflect the kind of delicious dishes the reastaurant is capable of.
author: Cristian G.

description:
Good mojito and sangria, but where is the most amazing drink on the planet(which also happens to be Peruvian btw)-- pisco sour?! How can you consider yourself "Peruvian" and not serve it?

Food was good, although I like Fresca a bit more. I think their Lomo saltado, ceviches, and other traditional Peruvian dishes are just better executed. Sorry, just my personal 2 cents.

3.5 stars.
author: Irina T.

description:
Truth be told, this restaurant used to knock my socks off when my husband took me a few years ago on a date. The service was efficient, friendly, and the food was authentic Peruvian cuisine.

This past November, I decided to take my husband there for his birthday. We had a group of about 12, and I made a reservation weeks in advance. I was assured a few times on the phone that I would get an upstairs table, with enough room to sit 12 guests comfortably. 

We got there, and some of our party was waiting at the bar already.
I was told by the underage hostess that it would be about 20 minutes. I was annoyed but could deal with that and stall. Another 20 minutes pass and I track down the restaurant manager, who looks like Chef Gordon Ramsey from "Hell's Kitchen". He confesses they screwed up our reservation and double-booked. Now I'm beyond upset, and trying to remain calm in front of guests. Apparently they forgot they were dealing with a New Yorker, not some hipster from the Mission.

And what did I get for getting screwed over? A round of free sangrias.
Thanks management -- for the cheap "shut up" mocktails. 

We were eventually seated, ended up getting an efficient waitress, so at least that wasn't another slap in the face. Food was okay but not as good as before.

I still enjoy their traditional ceviche, and would stop by just for that, but their full menu needs some revamping. Or maybe the chefs needs to get better with multi-tasking.

Salud!
author: Lara D.

description:
Hands down, the best overall dining experience I've had in SF so far: the food, the service, the ambiance, the location...everything.

The food/drinks:  The BEST sangria ever. EVER. I don't know what they put in it, but it tasted a bit sweeter than all the other sangrias.  We shared the Truffle Mac 'N Cheese and ceviche for our appetizer--I don't know much about ceviche so it's hard to judge, but I do know it tasted fresh.  The Mac 'N Cheese was incredible- white cheese is better than orange cheese.  The Lomo Saltado was delicious--I asked for the meat medium well, but it was still very tender.  My friends were very pleased with their dishes as well (rib eye, paella, fish).  For dessert, we had the Mango Pana Cotta; we didn't leave anything left over

The service: Our sangria and water were always full.  Our full party was 20 minutes late and they had our table waiting and saved for us (which was super nice).  They wiped down our table & always brought us new silverware for each course.  One friend had leftovers and they boxed it for her and brought it at the end of the meal (so that it didn't get in the way).  Extremely nice and attentive service.

The ambiance: Very clean, great decor, and a cute upstairs seating as well.  Even the bathroom was pretty and smelled good!

Location: Close to BART & Muni & parking isn't too bad, either.

For everything we ordered (and we ordered quite a bit), it was less than $50 for four of us.  Make reservations, because if you don't, you'll probably have to wait.  It was busy the entire time we were there.  As it should be--it was wonderful.
author: Cher B.

description:
I stumbled upon this place with my roommate on a regular weekend day, and thank goddess we did. It was a delightful and unexpected experience.

Location: Great location in between 16th and 17th and Valencia. Trendy, diverse and tons to do. Tons of bars, shopping, sex shops, etc. Perfect for taking friends out to eat.

Space: Pretty nice space. Not great or particularly interesting, but pretty tasteful. I've seen it before. Kind of that modern, Thai feel... even though it's a Peruvian restaurant. Lot's of tables, which is good.

Ambient: Pretty bougie in there. But at least it's diverse bougie. Age range is 25-45. Nice, descent, crowd.

Service: Really nice, cordial and fun service. Our server was a bit cold and then warmed up to us and made great rapport.

Drink/Food: The food was quite delicious. The ceviche, las empanadas, everything was really good--EXCEPT the couscous. Don't order the couscous, it's boring and not up to par with the rest of the food. The Sangria is sublime. It's not sweet and it's more velvety. It hits you without you knowing it, and that, that is what it's all about.

Overall: Great place to have a nice descent, yet exquisite, not too pricey and diverse dinner. There's tons to eat here, needless to say that we made it through the whole dinner with just appetizers. Definitely a place to try out.
author: SF N.

description:
First of all, I want to express that I do feel bad for giving this place 2 stars after reading all the great reviews but the food was truly a big disappointment.  But I must emphasize that the service was outstanding so on that alone I would give 5 stars!  Everyone from the host, to the server, to the "self proclaimed" sommelier and every other title you can think of gave their 100% to make our dining experience a great one.  And I must add that we were a group of 7 rowdy adults so patience was definitely a virtue!

Now onto the food and the drinks....

Ceviche - The mix of seafood was decent but the sauce was way to vinegary and too limey.

Chicken Skewers - SALTY!!

Grilled Octopus - The thickest tentacles I've ever seen...not quite tender enough, still on the tough chewy side.

Yucca - $5 for 6 giant french fries?!

Beef empanadas - Probably the best item we had on the menu.

Red Snapper - It was great presentation and texture of the fish was perfect...slight crisp on the outside but yet kept its moisture on the inside but unfortunately it was tasteless.  I'm not so much of a fan when you need to constantly dip something in thick sauce. 

Steak w/french fries - Flavor was good, meat was tender but lacked spark...nothing to rave about and at $22 you can get better else where.

Capriahana - $9 for sprite with lime juice and sugar?!  Where's the alcohol?

Overall, I was really disappointed in the quality and the quantity of the food for the price you pay.  For great Peruvian food and drinks, I will stick to La Mar...a bit pricey but never a let down!
author: Tina L.

description:
The one thing that I like the least here is the fact that they only seat complete parties. I can understand in a no-reservation place where you don't want other diners to hog the table and wait for their entourage to show up, 15-20 minutes late.  But when there were 20 of us, and we already made a reservation weeks in advance, surely you wouldn't wait for ONE last person to turn up before showing us the table that is already reserved and ready for us!

Okay - enough of that.

The rest of our experience was enjoyable.  Our server was lovely, our drinks were promptly served, and thank god for prix fixe menu because as soon as we got seated, the dishes started coming one by one.  

We had:
tartare de atun - ahi tuna tartare and crispy potato chips.  hands down one of the best tuna tartare i've ever sampled.
ceviche mixto - mixed tangy seafood cocktail.  generous serving of red snapper, octopus, calamari and shrimp mixed in lime juice and garlic
ensalada mixta - mixed green salad = the only guilt-free thing on the menu for the evening
pescado limon - simple yet delicious pan-fried battered fish
chicharron de pollo - their signature dish of fried chicken pieces
empanadas - almost like the peruvian version of chinese spring rolls

And those were JUST the appetizers.

For the main course we had the seafood paella, lomo salt ado (grilled skirt steak) and short ribs, served family style.  

And for $35 per person, it's definitely a good deal if you have a big group of people and don't feel like spending a bomb for a private room in other semi decent restaurants just to meet the minimum spend requirement!
author: Ange L.

description:
Limon is the best restaurant ever!  I recently had a birthday celebration in this venue.  Great food & drinks.  The ceviche', chicken, macaroni, yucca, & sangria are a must have.  

It's a cute, & trendy spot with a warm feel.  

Ladies, the bathrooms are clean & welcoming.

Limon is a must go!
author: Cybill M.

description:
Red Snapper Ceviche - very fresh, very good!!! :D 
Mac and Cheese - very strong truffle essence
Empanadas de Carne - Delicious 
Paella - Very nice presentation. Delicious too. Very saucy, a little spicy. 

Favorite: Ceviche. 

However, service is not great. We had to wait forever for our dishes and for our bill.
author: Catherine T.

description:
- over an hour wait with a reservation and no apology.
- kept being brushed off by the hostess with answers ranging from 'almost ready' to '20 minutes' every time we checked to see if our table's ready and no apologies.
- when finally seated, we were offered a small table for 6 to squeeze in a party of 7, no apologies .
- waited just over 10 minutes for our waiter to show up, he acknowledged our unfortunate incident, but no apologies.
- food was hit and miss.  not worth the wait.
- no discount nor free dessert were offered, neither did they apologize.
- when the bill came, 19% mandatory gratuity for poor management, okay food, mediocre service!!
- and if you're conscious about sustainable seafood, don't go.
author: kevin kc t.

description:
I actually returned to Limon sooner than expected.  I had to eat some more of their Ceviche Nikkei de Atun, which was still amazing.  I ordered their sangria and chicharron de pollo again. 

The other dishes I tried:
Choros Limon: Steamed PEI mussels with bacon, spicy pimento sauce, onions & chimichurri french fries - it was good but not great

Costillas Nikkei: Crispy spare ribs with Peruvian style slaw and rocoto-soy sauce - it was too sweet for me.  I actually enjoyed the slaw more than the ribs.

Pargo Rojo: Crispy red snapper fillet, coconut fried rice & rocoto-curry sauce - DELICIOUS.  Loved the presentation and everything on the plate.

Churrasco a la parilla: Grilled ribeye over sauteed vegies, crispy potatoes and chimichurri with red wine demiglaze - the steak was cooked perfectly, but it was not as flavorful as I expected it to be.  I've definitely had better churrasco in Miami.

For dessert we had the Bandido, which is a warm chocolate cake with light strawberry compote vanilla ice cream, caramel tuile & chocolate sauce and the Panna Cotta de Mango, which is mango and vanilla panna cotta with cinnamon tuile, mixed berry compote & moscat-berry sorbet.  Both were tasty, but I'm more of a chocolate lover so I enjoyed the bandido more.

There's still other dishes I haven't tried and I definitely want more ceviche.  This has become one of my favorite restaurants; not only is the food delicious, but the service is also great.
author: Sandy J.

description:
I had been looking forward to coming here for a while; the first time I came by, they were closed for renovation. 

But last night proved very disappointing. We were seated about 15 minutes after our reservation, which was fine understanding that this was a busy restaurant. 

But after we got seated, and ordered, the bread and water took 15 minutes to come (I had to remind our waitress, too). And 15 minutes later, there was the ceviche. And 30 minutes later, there was the main course. Quite depressing, considering the table next to us was seated at the same time and was gobbling up their red snapper and ribeyes during our 30-minute wait. 

Also, both the ceviche and the boring chicken entree we overly salty. 

Is the cooking staff here underpaid? Are they understaffed? I'm not sure, but for a 4-star Yelp rating, this place sucks. On the bright side, our waitress was nice. 

Maybe my experience next time might be better, but waiting for an hour for your food on an empty stomach can set you on the wrong foot, which is why I won't choose this place for another meal.

Limon is all glimmer and no gold.
author: Min L.

description: Food here is not good. Ceviche was tough, all I could taste in the beet salad was mayonnaise, chicken was mediocre/not special, and I think I tasted mold in one of the sauces. Drinks were also too sweet. And the bill came to $80 per person. This place used to be mediocre but ok value. Now I would say the food is not even worth eating.
author: Michele M.

description:
I've eaten here twice now and been impressed both times. The first time was on a Monday night for a business dinner and the second time was on a Sunday night with my fiancé. The cebiches are amazing. I've never liked octopus or calamari. Limon has me singing a different tune as I really like their cebiche with octopus and calamari. Tried Cebiche Limon last night - yum.

The Lomo Saltado is a must have. The first time I was there my colleagues ordered it (and thankfully shared). I ordered the Pork Chop. While the seasoning and garnish were wonderful, the chop itself was overcooked. Last night I ordered the Lomo Saltado and was not disappointed-medium rare wok tossed sirloin that melts in your mouth paired with onions, tomato, and French fries. 

One side dish that's not to be missed is the sweet potato fries. Crispy outside for that satisfying crunch seasoned with sea salt while perfectly cooked on the inside.

Service was fantastic-our water glasses were kept filled as were our wine glasses. We had a reservation on Monday and they were able to shift the time for us when we got stuck in traffic due to Market being closed due to a protest. We didn't have a reservation on Sunday-got there a little after 6-and were seated immediately. The main floor is a little loud. There's a booth/table for 5 that's insulated from mist of the noise and was great for our business dinner.
author: Eden S.

description:
[Disclaimer: I have learned, after two years in San Francisco, that "overpriced" is to popular restaurants what "naked, high hippies" are to Dolores Park: part of the culture! I no longer down-vote based on this criterion.]

Excellent food, beautifully presented by friendly staff in a tasteful environment. I was literally anxious after reading all the bad reviews, but found none of that during my visit: We were seated after being 30 min late for our Saturday evening reservation.

Insider Tip: The Sangria is one of the best I've had in the city, but you judge yourself whether that is worth $25 a pitcher.
author: Janett R.

description: This place is great for dinner! The food was great and the service was good. The ceviche was delicious. I also ordered a mango mojito also great!! My boyfriend made reservations ahead of time and we were seated right when we walked in, and there were people ahead of us!!
author: Christie M.

description:
Insanely good Peruvian food.  The service was also incredible .  The desert delayed a bit so they didn't charge for it.  And I didn't even think it took long.  

plates i recommend:

- Lomito Saltado
- Ceviche de Pescado
- Seco the Costillas
author: Edson C.

description:
Nice spot that was recommended by a friend who said it was his fav spot in the city. Came with a friend from LA for a light dinner. Great ambiance, had a tough time getting in. They seemed really surprised we didn't have a reservation but seated us within 10 mins. We ordered a bunch of apps, of which our fav was the ribs (Costillas Nikkei). Nice a crispy outside, juicy inside!

We'll def go back and check it out again!
author: Vernon L.

description:
Limon is okay, but not a good value.  A friend and I ordered the paella to compare it with what we had in Spain.  It cost $20, but was very small.  We were quite confused, but then realized it wasn't the sort of restaurant we wanted.  So we finished our "meal" and went to a coffee shop for desert.  

The appetizers and the beer were not that special either.  The prices of everything were in line with other restaurants, so we ordered the paella to share and got less then enough food for one person.

Yuca Fries: $3
Causa: $7
Beer (Cuzquena): $4
Paella: $20

We went on a Sunday at five (early) and it was dead.  No one was there.  The service was acceptable.  

It was unremarkable, predictable and boring.  If you're looking for food in the area, check out the places nearby.
author: Moses B.

description: Parking sucks, duh it's in the City, and the area around is ghetto. It was a busy wed night at 8:30pm.  We stepped in the basement, and our server showed great service.  It's roughly $10 a plate. Chicken was great. But a tad salty for us.
author: Hank C.

description:
This place was nicer than I expected considering the other surrounding restaurants/bars in the area. I mean come on a block away from delirium? It was surprisingly empty the night we came, which I guess is a good thing based on these past reviews claiming the wait is long even with reservations. Parking was a bit of a pain, as expected. 

It's nice that they actually actually offer vegetarian (one item in the entree list), unlike Limon Rotisserie, the other Peruvian restaurant with a similar name. Sangria was yummy minus the lemons. Sides (cocnut rice and sweet potato fries) were good, but are those really particular to Peruvian cuisine...? I guess this review is a little (okay, a lot) biased since I'm not able to taste the full spectrum of meaty options they offer, but overall it was fine but nothing spectacular.
author: Leily P.

description:
This restaurant comes as close to perfection as it gets, but a few missteps cost it half a star. 

The Rosco's Chicken with Gruyere Mac N Cheese was to die for. This thing hit a grand slam in my book and was a large reason why I wavered between a 4.5 and 5 stars. If foods could be juiced, I'd get the feds to check if they are sneaking a fast one by us. The chicken actually compares well to Zuni's roast chicken. The Mac N Cheese was probably the best I've had in my life. The slight stinkiness of the cheese complements the buttery cheese over soft tender macaroni.

So the juiced chicken and mac n cheese hit a home run, why not 5 stars? Let's start with the sangria. The Sangria tasted heavily watered down and was served with ice. Not sure what the rationale is, but it's poor form to serve wine or cocktails with ice and the same is true of sangria. The ice watered the drink down substantially.

The ahi tuna appetizer was very uninspired and too salty. Generally, the ahi tuna tartare trend is a good one or two years beyond it's prime. In consulting this is called a cash cow.

The Ceviche de Martini was excellent. It was a well balanced ceviche that innovates by adding a creamy yellowish sauce to counterbalance the sharp sour of a ceviche. 

Other good dishes include their interpretation of a paella (risotto with prawns) and a fried fish with curry.

Great place to celebrate something special, and certainly a place worth celebrating.
author: Andrew H.

description: One of my new favorite places to eat in the city.  I wish I could remember the names of all the foods I tried there though.  The chicken was def the best, very flavorful and moist.  We had the combination ceviche which was very tasty as well.  The truffell macaroni was also a big hit with everyone.  I've been there twice and each time the food came out very quickly.  Good place if you like tapa's style food.
author: Jeremy W.

description: My friend lived in Peru for 2 years and took me to this spot for some Peruvian food as he claims its one of the better spots in San Francisco.  And I have to agree, they have really good rotisserie chicken here and it's great for sharing!  Their fries are also super delicious.  What I like about this place is that everything was pretty simple and they didn't seem like they were trying to over do anything.  Also had a couple cocktails which were also pretty good.  I would definitely recommend the maracuya sour!  The passion fruit sweetness and sourness really balances each other out.
author: Keri K.

description:
I agree with other reviewers about the ceviche.
I had the ceviche sampler (you get to choose from 3 different ceviches on the menu with sauces $18)
It was amazing, very fresh and they give you huge chunks of fish.

I am deducting one star, because as some reviewers mentioned the servers keep coming up to your table it seems every 3 minutes to check if you have finished your meal so they can take your plate away; very annoying.

FYI, the sangria is all right if you like them REALLY sweet.
author: Brenda I.

description:
were walking around the area when we saw this place and said gosh their menu looks delicious. Got a little turned off when they said come back in 10 minutes because they weren't open yet ( could offered us a seat at the bar, sir). Walked around the block to see if something else would entice our appetite (with the boss+colleague). nothing else did so i kept nudging to give the place a chance. and soooo glad we did!

Everything we had was delicious! We had oyster and limon shooters, I had the Anticucho de Pollo, the colleague had the empanada, the boss had the Pescado Limon. 

After lunch, I was still dreaming about my food. Over the weekend, I was still dreaming of my food. Will definitely be back sooner than later!
author: Sheena S.

description:
Ok- this place is hip & happening.....we (my husband and I) had an amazing experience from the friendly and accommodating hostess to the great ambiance. The meal burst with such wonderful flavors; best rib-eye ever. 
Coming back soon for sure!
author: Julie Z.

description:
My second visit here was a little disappointing: Ceviche Limon was way overdone in the citrus department and was strong and tart I could barely eat it all.  I ended up digging out the fish pieces the best I could and shaking off the sauce.

Rib-eye steak was decent but the potatoes and sauce were just average.  Wine list isn't extensive, interesting or high quality enough for a restaurant that aspires to "fine dining".
author: Nick A.

description:
Came here for brunch / lunch and really enjoyed the short ribs. Most delish!

Service was great at well (friendly & knowledgeable) - not your average SF indifferent attitude.

Nice atmosphere too.

Important to remember: this is a a tapas place.
author: Al B.

description:
Ah, so delicious!  A dear friend brought me to this restaurant after I started complaining of hunger pangs while simultaneously verbalizing my NEED for a pisco sour.  I was more than pleased. I'm in town visiting, and come from a place where Peruvian fare is not easily available, so I jumped at the chance to come here.

Here's a list of all the things we ordered- there were 6 of us and we finished every.single.plate...I may have even scooped up some sauce with my fingers...maybe:

Drinks:  
2 Mojito Limons
2 Strawberry Sours (I swear, a frothy little bit of love)
1 Mango Mojito (a friend asked for it to be made not too sweet, which    was great because it seemed as if all the natural flavors were enhanced rather than just being overpowered with juice)
1 Stella

Apps/Entrees:

We decided to share a whole bunch of appetizers and 2 entrees.

Ceviche Limon- mixed seafood, and so, so fresh!

Tiradito de Atun-ahi tuna ceviche


Empanadas de Carne-  delicious, with the perfect flaky crust to meat ratio

Mac and Cheese- oh dear God- amazing...but only if you like truffle sauce

Pulpo- octopus with mashed potatoes- sounds strange, but delicious and chewy- they give you whole octopus (mini ones), so it's not for the faint of heart.

Paella- unfortunately, I didn't have this, but I was assured that it was spicy, saucy, piping hot with lots of succulent seafood.  This is also one of the restaurant's more popular dishes

Pollo Latino-  I feel like you can't come to a Peruvian restaurant without having peruvian chicken- it was delicious.  The chicken was juicy with a crispy, papery skin.  It came with mushroom mashed potatoes, broccoli, some spicy sauce, and some red wine sauce.  ah.

The service was fine- nothing really special there.  Our dishes came out on time, our waiter was fine- maybe a little harried, but nothing out of the ordinary.  It's also not as expensive as I thought it would be.  All together, the bill came out to about $170- which wasn't bad considering we ordered the entire menu.  

It's well worth a trip back here.
author: Danielle S.

description:
You Guys!

Something about Limon has changed.  I used to really think it was excellent and very tasty, but I just recently went, and the food was very salty especially the sauces, and I just wasn't impressed with the menu anymore.  

Our pork chop had a good flavor, but it was a little chewy, my dish came out a little cold and I just felt like the noise was overwhelming and almost impossible to hold a conversation (we sat upstairs).

I would like to add that the customer service was great however, they brought us a complimentary dessert because one of our pork chops came out pretty late.  The dessert was the best part of the meal.
author: Denise M.

description:
With so many reviews, I'll just mention what we had tonight that made for an excellent meal!

1. Oyster shooters - yummy.  Unlike most oyster shooters where you can't taste the oysters, the "leche de tigre" sauce really worked well with the briny oysters.

2.  Limon Cebiche - loved the calamari in this dish!

3.  Whole crispy red snapper  - so delicious and what a dramatic presentation.  The curry sauce, served on the side, is yummy with the fried fish.  

4.  Grilled Ribeye - perfectly done the way we asked (medium rare).  Great seasoning!

5.  Profiteroles - we were tempted to get another order of this dessert.  Tasted wonderful and I highly recommend it.   Loved the rasberry sauce with it!

Lastly, I slurped the sauces that came with the bread, particularly the one made out of peruvian chilies, cilantro, and egg (we asked what was in it).  Everything was amazing!  You won't be disappointed.
author: Abby N.

description: Fair prices but the food was just OK, was expecting better. Sitting downstairs is not a good option...your sat in the basement which still needs finishing! Service was pretty good.
author: Trevor W.

description:
Service was very good but the food was uninspired and lacked flavor.
We were disappointed.

I've been here a year prior and the food was much better.

To begin we had the Pollo small plate which was basically deep fried chicken, nothing special and too greasy. Taste was mediocre. For appetizers we also had the beet salad which was basically drizzled in mayonnaise...yummy. j/k.  Then we had the Quinoa which was the better of the 3.

For our main courses we had the Red Snapper entree and Duck Entree. The fish was pan-fried and had very little flavor... nothing special, we could have had the same at a Taqueria and paid a 1/4 of the cost.

The $84 price tag for two was not worth the lack of flavors. 
The $5 sangria was indeed a bargain and the best item we had during our visit

We skipped dessert as we struck out with the above mentioned. I was ready for the disappointment to end.

Too many good restaurants in our beautiful city in this price range then to come here. 

Limon, I think your sun has set.
author: M E.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for some time now. So when I saw the Groupon there was no turning back, Limon I'm coming for you. 

I came here with two others who were both looking for something new to try on a Tuesday afternoon. After reading reviews about the crowds, I called ahead to make sure there would be no wait. We arrived at the restaurant and as promised by the hostess on the phone, we were promptly seated. The service was great, recommendations were given, change of plates and utensils after the ceviche, never empty water glasses, and a waitress who always walked by to make sure everything was okay! 

Amongst us we shared: 

Ceviche Limon: Nom. Nom. Nom. I could eat this all day. Each individual flavor of the fish, the shrimp, and the calamari really shined through with the help of the acid. Definitely an appetite opener, it made me want more and more. 

Lomo Saltado: I'm a little torn about the Lomo Saltado here. It was good, but just not as flavorful as the one I had before at Fresca. 

Pescado Limon: Served on a bed of potatoes and spinach, the red snapper was outstanding. It was flakey and delicious. Is it wrong that I liked the spinach a little more than the snapper though? 

Chicharron de Pollo: This crispy chicken could have been really bad without the sauce on the side, as it was a bit dry. But the tangy sauce saved the dish and had me going back for more. 

Truffle Infused Mac and Cheese: I don't think there could ever be anything wrong with mac and cheese. This one was creamy and delicious. Nothing too overpowering, it was just the right flavor and texture. 

Overall, it was a delicious and fun lunch with my girls. And not hard on the wallet either. Including the price of the Groupon, we only had to pay $15 each for all the dishes we tried!
author: Adrianna C.

description: Limo is great but I didn't find a new obsession there so I can't give it 5 stars. This is bc I'd been wanting to try Peruvian chicken since my freshman year, 5 yrs ago when I was just a country mouse in a big new city but always hesitated cuz it's jist chicken! That's the problem, it was still just chicken. It wasnt mind blowing like my first french rosemary rotis or my first crunch of korean fried chicken (OMG).The chicken and sides are darn good and so is the service and ambience. And price! If you split the chicken and carefully choose small plates, it's pretty affordable. It's also good that the waiters aren't cheesy, pushing you to order more.
author: Ingrid K.

description:
Came here for a very belated Valentine's Day dinner celebration w/ the bf (we're born procrastinators) since he was in NY on the cursed day.

Walked in around 7:00 PM and grabbed 2 seats by the bar, where we were greeted by the nicest, most friendly bartender ever.  I don't know if it's the sangria-hangover talking, but I am in love with her.  We ordered the Causa de Pollo, Mariscos, Pollo Latino, Pargo Rojo, a side of Truffled Mac'n Cheese, and a carafe of sangria.

Let's do business right and start off w/ the sangria, which was one of the best I've had.  My friends will tell you that I'm a big sangria girl, and I loved that even after we polished off our carafe, the bartender came around and refilled our glasses.  (Did I mention that I love her?)

The food was all pretty good, but I think we were both more taken by the sauces in every dish than the actual food itself.  The chicken was incredibly salty though (even to my bf, whose diet consists of about 90% sodium and 10% fat), and we had to send it back.  That was the first time I ever sent back a dish (peasant girl becomes a member of bourgeois?), since I was raised by strictly traditional Asian parents to never complain about food or waste it.  That might explain why I was such a chubster as a child.

Finished the dinner w/ the Bandido, a molten chocolate cake w/ vanilla ice cream, which I can't objectively critique since by then I was in a very happy place from the sangria.  I would've licked the dirt off my boots at that point.

Will probably go back for the sangria.  Oh, and to stalk the bartender of course.
author: Jen L.

description: Another great spot for peruvian food. Good atmosphere. Yum sangrias!!! Too bad is hard to find parking around there(but so is everywhere in sf..) not cheap,but good meal!
author: Tatiane B.

description:
I stumbled upon this restaurant with some friends who were in town and couldn't have had a nicer meal.  It was my first experience at a Peruvian restaurant so instead of ordering a single entree, I went for a combination of a couple appetizers and side dishes (that's my excuse for ordering in excess, and I'm sticking to it)....

Sangria is delicious, half a carafe gives you about 1.5 glasses for 2 people.

Limon cebiche; very fresh, simple, delicious taste.  I'm going to go ahead and assume many of the other cebiche dishes are equally fresh and tasty.

Crispy yucca & chimi churri: I admittedly didn't know what yucca even was before this (a root?) and oh my goodness...I need to learn how to prepare this at home!

Pollo al Meringue (braised sliced chicken breast in adreso-picante sauce): Simple preparation of chicken, the sauce is what makes it great.

Truffled mac n cheese: A grown up twist on a childhood favorite. Yum.

Sweet potato fries: I honestly don't know why more restaurants don't serve this version of fries...they make typical french fries seem so boring and flavorless! Sweet potato fries at Limon give ketchup the finger...no condiments needed.

The best part of the meal is when I *thought* I was flagging down a waiter to ask for more bread and it turned out to be Emmanuel Piquera, one of the head chefs!  He was insanely kind and friendly, bringing out a complimentary dish of lobster cebiche that wasn't on the menu for us to sample.  He clearly took pride in his work and his extra effort to spend time with us didn't go unnoticed...it's why Limon gets 5 stars from me.
author: Tricia N.

description:
winner winner chicken dinner. the concept is simple, chicken chicken and chicken, but the execution is bangin'. a whole rotisserie chicken for $19.90 (enough for 2 hungry people) including 2 sides and 3 dipping sauces.

now, the chicken is a basic rotisserie, done well, but still just regular 'ol chicken---however the sauces really bring the tasty. the sides are good---we got sweet potato fries, yum, and tacu tacu which is their beans and rice. it was good, but i don't think i'd order it again.

the service at Limon is what really elevates this place to a 5 star-er. they had the food out in minutes after ordering (much appreciated as we were ravished!) and they were incredibly attentive, helpful, and good spirited. Not to mention the host (floor supervisor maybe?) honored our reservations and seated us immediately despite a mix up that landed us at the wrong Limon location! oops! 

it gets really crowded so i recommend making reservations (and showing up at the right location! ha)
author: Melissa N.

description: I've been meaning to leave this review for a while. Limon is my favorite Peruvian restaurant in the city. Their ceviche is out of this world good and I can't get enough of their veggie empanadas.
author: Lauren V.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for our 4 year anniversary. We wanted to try another type of ethnic dish rather than getting the same food we have already tried. At first, it was hard to find parking, you have to park in the surrounding neighborhood. There was a crowd of people waiting to be seated so I recommend to make a reservation. We ordered the rotisserie chicken, seco de cosillias, vegetales saltedos and arroz. The dessert,  bandido (warm chocolate cake with caramelized apples, dulce leche ice cream, caramel tuile and chocolate sauce) was sweet and delicious. If only they served more food on the side dishes everything would be cool. Other than that, peruvian food never tasted so yummy!
author: Carrie S.

description: After a couple of tasty drinks the food always tastes better. I had a pisco sour and a la divina if I recall, Claps to whoever was pouring those drinks because they were strong. Friends and I decided on an entree and and some small plates to share. I did like the empanadas and jalea  but Im not much of a meat eater so that probably had a lot to do with why I wasnt impressed with everything else. The dessert was to die for though. Some kind of chocolate lava cake, Amazing!. Its the Mish so parking is a bitch if you drive. There is a parking garage on the corner though. Service was great. Super friendly server and its a nice clean spot.
author: Lauren N.

description: Terrific value on the pitcher of sangria. The chicken was excellent and highly recommend the Mac and cheese and tuna.
author: Dave C.

description:
I cam here on a Friday around 7pm and was quickly seated. I though the ceviche was pretty darn good. We ordered the Chicharron which was moist and tasty. The entres were decent. One was pretty much a slab of steak peruvian style but it did not impress me. The other was steak and onions with a hint of cilantro which was pretty interesting.

Sangria was good, I personally enjoy it more than Cha Cha Cha's
author: Eric A.

description: After hearing about this famous place from dozens of people, I finally got a taste of it a few weeks ago! Yummmm, they sold me on the pisco drinks alone! I am half Argentinean and the menu had similarities of back home given they are a South American country as well. I enjoyed the food, the drinks and the overall ambiance! I am planning to take my Mom for her birthday next month! I know she will enjoy it. :)
author: ST1223 T.

description:
i had my birthday dinner there the food was GREAT but the service sucked!! we had to wait for about 1 hour to get seated, after we already had reservations.  Would i throw another dinner party there NO!!

HOWEVER,
what I LOVE About this place is there happy hour && "DAVID" the bartender!!   We only sit at the bar..
The food is delicious!!
I love the oyster shooters, ceviches, & chicharron de pollo. the empandadas are alright...

the drinks are the BOMB!! love the mojitos, pink lemon drop && my favorite the SANGRIA!!! definately a happy hour!!

LOVES IT!!!
author: nina s.

description: Wonderful place. $10 for rotisserie chicken seems expensive, but calling it rotisserie chicken is also an insult to this place's chicken. What does rotisserie chicken conjure up for you? Tough meat covered with a blackened and extremely salted crust that was once "skin"? Well, that's how rotisserie chicken is everywhere besides Limon. Limon's Pollo a la Brasa is really moist and perfectly seasoned. It even comes with your choice of two sides! We got the Yuca Fries, which were alright, and Tacu-Tacu, which is a Great Peruvian version of rice and beans. The Tacu-Tacu was salty. We also got beef heart and Ceviche Mixto. I enjoyed both of the appetizers immensely.
author: Alan H.

description:
I came here on a date with my two girlfriends.  We wanted to try something out of our norm, So Peruvian it was!  There was already a small crowd gathered outside the restaurant upon our arrival, luckily we had made reservations in advance.  We were led to the basement of restaurant where the rest of the patrons were dining.  At the appropriate hour, the basement can definitely turn into a little lounge / club room.  

I forgot the proper names of the food we had, but I remember having their well known chicken, we had pork and beef and green beans, sweet potato fries, and stuff.  It was tasty and very tapa-ish....so the portions were pretty small.  The service was good too, and the ambience was just a tad bit too loud.
author: Shirley H.

description: Been here a couple of times now, and just like everyone, I'd say the chicken is the shiznit! The dipping sauces are great, and the truffle mac and cheese is awesome!
author: Ego F.

description:
We celebrated one of my girlfriends' birthday here a month ago and although it was good, not worth five star. More of a 3-1/2 star experince.
I've really enjoyed my lunch one time at Limon Rotisserie so I had big expectation for Limon. Looking at the website, my girlfriends and I expected it to be a more of an upscale, sit down restaurant but it was more of a tapas bar. The place was very casual and loud. Food was good but not over the top. More eclectic than expected with curry sauce & such. Creative platings though. Had better sangria else where.
author: Sooey B.

description: Oh so delicious!  Have been here on a few occassions.  There are so many delicious restaurants in the neighborhood I have a difficult time repeating but this is on the repeat list.  Food is so good!  Check it out
author: Heather K.

description: Came here a while back on my anniversary and enjoyed it! Prices are cheap (to me at least) and their drinks are yummy. I got pretty hammered that night and ended up barfing all my food out, so basically I wasted my dinner here. But I really enjoyed it before I actually got to drinking. I had their steak (forgot the name),short ribs (bf ordered) and fries. I'll be back, soon.
author: Colette P.

description:
I actually feel a little bad giving Limon only 4 stars - realistically, 4.5 is probably fairer, giving how amazing how many things about our dinner were.

We started with the "Limon" ceviche (fish, calamari, and shrimp) and the Empanadas de Carne (classic empanadas filled with beef, raisins, egg, & onion & served with a tasty sauce).  Both were amazing.  Everything in the ceviche tasted amazingly fresh, and the marinade gave it an amazing flavor.  Ditto for the empanadas.  The beef was flavorful and tender, and the pastry had the perfect texture.

Initially, we'd chosen a bottle of muscat to go pair with our ceviche, but the waiter returned with a sample of a different wine (not one I'd hear of before, but sounded Spanish and started with an A) that he thought might complement the ceviche better.  We tasted it and were impressed enough to order a bottle; it went with the ceviche perfectly.

For dinner, I got the Lomo Saltado (wok-tossed sirloin fingers with onion, tomato, soy sauce, and topped with French fries).  The texture of the beef was perfect and went really well with the onions & tomatos (I discarded the French fries, because they seemed pretty ordinarily & probably just garnish).  A bit salty because of the soy sauce, but then again, soy sauce.  Still really tasty.

My boyfriend ordered the Pollo Latino (baked chicken breast, stuffed red peppers, and truffle infused mac & cheese).  We both agreed that the chicken was perfectly cooked and amazingly flavorful.  His only complaint was that the truffle flavor in the mac & cheese was a little too subtle.

For dessert, we had a delicious sweet cheese dessert topped with chocolate.  (Unfortunately I don't remember anything else about the specifics, and it isn't listed on the online menu.)  Quite tasty.

Also, let me say that the service was absolutely flawless.  As in, some of the best service I've encountered anywhere I've ever been.  Our waiter was composed, friendly, knowledgeable, and seemed to have a sixth sense about when we were ready to order or needed something.  Our wine and water glasses were never empty, and our table was bussed and silverware replaced after every course (and typically within 10-20 seconds of finishing it).  Service definitely gets 5 stars.

My only real complaint about the food was the variation in available fish.  Nearly all the fish dishes (including most of the ceviche) was partly or all red snapper, which we forwent for environmental / sustainability reasons.  (I have a sneaking suspicion that the "fish" in the Limon ceviche that we ended up ordering was red snapper, but we reasoned that at least there was less of it than if we'd ordered one of the others.)

Bravo, Limon!  I wouldn't mind stopping by again.
author: Angela B.

description:
ok this used to be one of the places i ordered fish, and i dont like fish. they have deep fried red snapper that was curled when fried, the taste was extra-ordinary again I dont like fish, there are only 2 places that I order fish that is on the menu this is one of them the other is in a salad at the houstons restuarant in sf by the pier.

it was really loud everytime i went to this location, mixed drinks pricey but keep you asking for more after having one, ceviches dishes all of them were good, service depending on the nite can be good or irritating if crowded no refills, if empty you got more attention from waiters..

again this is one of 2 places i ordered fish that was on the menu by far that is 5 star in my book, everything else on the menu ehh was regular nothing too fancy just the snapper stuck out.

food ***** (snapper only)
price $$$
service ** 2 1/2 depends on if busy or empty.
author: Clarence A.

description: Have been in here twice after working downtown. Would highly recommend it! First time in, pretty dead at 4pm on a weekday, but felt really comfortable chilling with a kiwi martini and a couple tapas. Second time around, took a date, had a couple too many (delicious) pisco sours. Awesome bartender, dennis, was very attentive even though he was balls to the wall busy. 8pm on a friday night 10 minute wait for a table, but just decided to hang out and chow at the bar. Will be back soon!
author: Richelle A.

description:
You get quality food and a reasonable portion.  Well worth the price.  The tuna tartar and beef empanadas was delicious.  This was our second time. The first time we were here we had dinner. On Saturday, we had lunch. Both experiences were great. 

 Food = Delicious quality food

 Price = Reasonable

 Service = Moderate

We will be back.
author: Vic M.

description:
Zagat rated the food of this place at 23, it really should be a 17.

While the Empanadas de Carne was decently good, the rest of the items that we ordered was more than a bit disappointing. The Ceviche Limon wasn't bad, but was the fish didn't seem like it was sushi grade. The sweet potato fried of the Anticuchos de Pollo were delicious, but the chicken itself was too dry and flavorless. For the Chuleton Carlitos, the pork chops were again too dry, like it was overcooked by about five minutes, and the cabbage-bacon hash was way, way too salty.

Don't let this place be a wasted meal for you, too.
author: Chaz C.

description: A bit expensive and the portions are small. The empanadas are not worth the $7 - too small, and you only get two pieces! The seco de costillos was delicious though - very tender meat and rich sauce.
author: Ivana N.

description:
Definitely our favorite  Peruvian restaurant!!!  Quality of food and size of portions so worth the price PLUS you get outstanding service!!! Came in on Tuesday around 6pm, the restaurant was half empty, but around 7 it started to fill up, so better make reservation unless you have 15-30 min extra to hang around....
We had civiche limon, amazing!!! all kinds of seafood, lots of juice, was placed  very presentable on a plate. Then ordered 2 small plates, I don't remember it's name as it was in the menu, but something like fried fish with lemon sauce, potatoes , and second plate was chicken, very good, nice flavor and perfect size! Again, everything was nicely placed on the plate. I'm not a big fan of chicken at all, but I really liked this one! recommend it. Then our main course came out which was steak (med) with potatoes and onion rings. Still remember that Delicious  Taste!!!! 
For drinks I had a sangria, very good, not overloaded with ice or syrup.... My BF had  beer. We are just regular costumers, not  big eaters, and thought  were very very hungry ( last meal was oatmeal for breakfast on that day)  and still we took home some food left ( out of 1 civiche, 2 small plates and 1 main course)
So highly recommend to come here! Love this cuisine, love this restaurant, and you will love it too!!!!!!!
author: ina a.

description:
We started out with a the anticuchos de pollo and they were really good. the chicken was cooked to perfection and the sauces they served it with was really good. 
I had the pork shops with cabbage and bacon. DELICIOUS. the pork was wonderfully flavorful, and the cabbage, potato and bacon ragout was unreal.
My husband had the snapper and he ate the whole thing and then started picking at the bones like he had never eaten before! haha, it was really good. The Rocoto Curry sauce it's served with is pretty delicious. I would have ordered it myself, but the rice was made with coconut. He loved it, but I didn't because I simply don't like coconut.

If you love key lime, try it there, the crust was good and the pie was tart. 
The only reason I gave it 4 stars was that I miss the calamari there :(  and the service was a little tiny bit slow, but I'm sure they will work out there kinks since they only just reopened.
author: bree m.

description: All hype. This place and other restaurants on Valencia are for hipsters that think they're eating top notch Latin cuisine. Over priced for the rich computer tech fools, the flavors were something I can make at my house on a lazy day. They rush you out of there like your a drunk uncle at thanksgiving. FOR REAL LATINO FOOD GO A BLOCK DOWN TO MISSION ST. Not so flashy but the food is from the heart and soul. Actually funny thing after Limon I wasn't satisfied with the taste or small portion so I went literally a block down next to Mission to get pupusas from a lady making them outdoors. Sooo much better
author: Max H.

description: Limon is outstanding.  I've been there at least ten times.  Its casual, and for a pretty reasonable cost, you get food that is as good, and arguably better, than some of the priciest restaurants in the city.  The rotisserie chicken is particularly good, and the ceviche is the best I've ever had.
author: brett b.

description: always good, solid choice and yummy!!
author: Michael L.

description: Amazing food, u can't go wrong here. The mac n cheese was delicious. Since they have remodeled its a more casual place so dont bother getting dolled up.  Prices are affordable and pretty good portion for a tapas.
author: Nadiya M.

description:
OK... first let me start by saying this is not "PERUVIAN" food 

But it is hella Good!

High quality ingredients... and the food is hands down TASTY.

The only down side is the Price... and If you are a big meal type person...these are little female portions i'm watching my weight.

But still very tasty...anywho.... I've been back there three times because it just tastes good...

Recommend:

Ribs
Lomo saltado
mac n cheese with truffles...
author: Alejandro C.

description:
Enjoyed dinner here last night. I have been living in San Francisco for almost 3 years and I have heard so many great things about Limon. I must say that it was fabulous! I enjoyed the carne empenadas and then the Pollo. AMAZING! The presentation of our dishes was out of this world! Impressive! Their wines by the glass were also fabulous!

Cannot wait to eat here again!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Came here for dinner this past Saturday with some old friends, one who was visiting from LA.  

My initial impression was pretty good.  There was a good vibe going, and the staff was pretty nice.  But then I found out they screwed up the reservation.  Wrong time, wrong amount of people.  Not a huge deal, b/c they just fixed it.  By fixing it, it's just crossing out the time and number, which looking back isn't fixing anything.  Reservations don't seem to mean anything here.  There were 3 groups including ours that had to wait over an hour after the reservation time.  

Anyways, on to the food.  The ceviche and empanadas are money.  Must haves.  They are absolutely incredible.  A little expensive for what you get, but not outrageously so.  For entrees, we had pork chops, chicken, and a red snapper dish.  All of them were very well done and well presented.  However, the pork chops and chicken were dishes I could have easily done at home.  When I go out, it's nice to have things that I can't throw together in my own kitchen.  

For Limon, that's the ceviche and empanada, and that's about it.
author: Dietrich H.

description:
Yummy and GREAT ambiance!  i really like this place for many reasons.  First impression was such a lively clientele.  We walked in on a Friday night and it seemed like such a fun crowd.  Everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves and enjoying their food.  

Ceviche here is quite delicious.  We had two different kinds and both of them were very flavorful and delicious.  We also had the ribeye and pork chop.  Both very good.  The ribeye had a very good potato based under it and the pork chop came on a bed of sauteed cabbage and bacon.  So delicious!  

The drinks were good as well.  They don't have a full bar but I had a mango mojito made with soju and it was pretty good.  I likes.  I would definitely go back here.  Thanks Limon!
author: Jaein L.

description:
CEVICHE CEVICHE CEVICHE

All is care for is ceviche. The rest of the menu is good but the ceviches were amazing. Next time I am sitting at the bar and just indulging in ceviches and appetizer menu. I did like the service so no offense wait staff--you are nice and attentive.  Go and eat at Limon! and have a INKA Cola :)
author: Florencia P.

description: Limon, Limon, Limon, where do I begin?  To make this short and sweet... this place is an all-time favorite.  The food never disappoints and the sangria's are always delicious.  Every time we have a girl's night out, we start off with dinner and sangrias here.  Then end up leaving at 11pm tipsy and full from eating and drinking.  The plates are small but filling.  I personally love the Lomo Saltado, Jalea, and Empanadas.  This place gets really busy for dinner so make sure to book a reservation or get there early.  Also, street parking can be a pain but then again, we are in San Francisco.
author: Cynthia P.

description:
I can understand the complaints about portion sizes. However, that can be easily rectified if you make sure to order some type of protein from the entree menu.

Three of us ordered 1 entree, 1 ceviche, 1 appetizer, 1 of the other category, and one side, and it was enough, and only $23/person.

Everything was delicious, and very carefully prepared; so tender....
author: Mark A.

description: Bad service. Nobody greets you when you walk in. I was seated and given the menu. Waiter didn't ask me if I wanted to order a beverage. Someone came up to me to ask and had someone else bring it to me? I felt as if I was disturbing them. I sat there for 10 mins watching the waiters pass by me while I waited to order. A group of 4 sat next to me and were given water and served them wine while helping them to order? What is wrong with this picture? I decided to pay for the soda I ordered but was given to me on the house. I left it anyway. Glad I didn't spend my money there for lunch.
author: Christina R.

description:
I'd rate this place a 3.5, but round up to a 4. The wait was kinda long, but that doesn't affect the 4 star rating. I too, went there to try the rotisserie chicken because it was on the 7x7 list of things to try in San Francisco. Surprise, they ran out of chicken. We thought we'd explore other things on the menu, although we were still kinda bummed.

Everything was really delicious I must say. The sangria is one of the best I've had, and I might go here for a brunch kinda deal where I'm not looking to get full, because the dish size definitely wouldn't do anything for my appetite if I was hungry. The lomo was yummy, as was the ceviche. Overall, the food was great. Downside, small portions, and no chicken. I might try it out again, after I've finished eating somewhere prior to going to Limon.
author: Alvin P.

description:
I'm sad that I didn't go to the right Limon!  No rotisserie chicken for me...

But still a good experience here at Limon tonight.  My friend and I had already eaten a taco so we just ordered a couple things.  

Ceviche de Pescado. They are so generous with the ceviche and you actually get mini filets of fish.  Most places I've been to give you tiny chunks.  Not only did we get a little mound of it, it was very tasty.  Even my friend who typically doesn't like ceviche loved it for its refreshing and light flavors.  Would definitely go back for this!  And at $12, it's a steal.

Empanadas de Carne. Very tasty.  They only give you two but it is completely filled with deliciousness.  I'm not too sure what was in there except beef and some raisins but it was wonderfully seasoned and spiced.  Yum...a little more on the expensive side for just two empanadas but worth trying.

Yucca fries - Who doesn't love yucca fries?? Perfectly crispy topped with chimi churri. P.S. WAAAY better than Fresca's yucca fries!!!   

I wish we were hungrier so that we could have tried more!  But the appetizers was more than enough to win me over!  Can't wait to try the other Limon.
author: Helen V.

description: Limon is one of those places that actually lives up to the hype. The chicken is moist, well-seasoned, and absolutely delicious. The ceviche is incredibly well-made and the leche-de-tigre seasoning is just amazing. Overall a fun experience as everything is family-style. The only complaint is that it's rather noisy, so conversations are difficult.
author: Ti Z.

description:
out out out

Come on now, this isn't baseball.

Empanadas - Out
Fish - Out
Why bother - Out

Had to wait for a seat, but that fine and dandy as we had the option to wait at the bar or lounge area. Sangria accompanied us as we waiting to be seated.  With company like that who would complain.  Ok so what was ordered was the Mac and Cheese, thumbs up, Rissotto, good, and Rib Eye, cooked to perfection but a bit on the small side. Molten chocolate cake was the DH and didn't quite hit out of the park. Service was professional and prompt.
author: Po L.

description:
5 years ago I would have given them 4.5, but besides the decor it's not even the same place.

The menu has been simplified so that everything is pre-cooked and tastes like fast food.
Anything that used to be made to order is gone. The ceviche is good, but there are many other places to get good ceviche.

We went for a celebratory dinner expecting to take our time but had our appetizers, small plates and  entrees all thrown at us before they could even mix our cocktails... you can not cook real paella faster than pouring a martini.

If we hadn't made it clear that we would not be leaving 'till the bottle of wine was finished we would have been herded out the door. We actually had to hold on to the bottle so they wouldn't take it away.
author: Elaine I.

description:
This place is AMAZING!!!!  The Rib-Eye was to die for.  I can't wait to try the Ceviche next time.  My only complaint would be that they need actual salt and pepper shakers, they just have bowls with salt and pepper in them, and you use a spoon to use it, I ended up over salting, but then again I love salt.

Tried the Ceviche, it was amazing, but have been there recently and now the portion sizes are tiny, bring back the bigger size, it's pretty ridiculous.
author: Jason B.

description:
I had the intention of visiting "Limon Rotisserie" and not this Limon location. I only realized after we sat down but I will have to visit Limon Rotisserie someday. I have to try the chicken and casual tapas menu.   


Anyways...service was good but the waitress forgot to give me back my doggie bag and I forgot to ask her.  The place was packed on a Monday night.  It's right off 16th/Mission BART station so it is easily accessible by public transportation.  Parking is hit or miss. I parked on 18th/Guerrero and it was a 2 hour limit until 9pm.

Since my friend did not like raw cerviche, I did not order it. I'll have to try it at the Rotisserie Limon someday. 

We ordered this appetizer:

Costillas Nikkei- crispy spare ribs with Peruvian style slaw and rocotto-soy sauce (Pretty soft and tasty) $10

Seco de Cordero- Lamb shank braised in huacatay-cilantro broth with veggies over tacu-tacu $20 (Very good but SALTY)

Picanted de Pescado & Camarone- fresh fish fillter and tiger shrimp cooked in aji amarillo creamy sauce with potatoes & tacu tacu $19 

Dessert:

Bandido- warm chocolate cake with strawberry compote and Vanilla ice cream $8
author: Jboogie L.

description: Great bang for your buck! I have been here twice now, and each time I was pleasantly surprised by the attentiveness of the staff, and the unique twists on classic Spanish dishes. I would recommend splitting a whole chicken between groups of four or more---the meat falls right of the bone and is cooked to keep its succulent flavor. Fritos are a great side as was the truffle mac and cheese. A good spot to share tapas between friends where the value exceeds expectations.
author: Culinary C.

description: I was really unimpressed with Limon Rotisserie on s van ness, but I come here (16th and valencia) as often as I can. Everytime I'm here my taste buds get high off the flavor flav. The lomo saltado and pescado are awesome, drinks are good, service is good, and it's big so you always get seated fast. love you limon!
author: Kim P.

description:
GREAT EMPENADAS :)  

My bf took me here last night since it was my birthday and We didnt make any plans hence my tummy wasnt feeling well all week :( Any how, I enjoyed the Empenadas and Sangria very much... However, the tuna ceviche was very sour... and the tuna grade wasnt very great either, I had to spit some parts out because it wasnt chewable!:( Im a huge fan of sushi, so i know what's GOOD tuna! As for our entrees, My bf got the Lamb Shank and I had the Pork chops... Everything was over seasoned! :/ At least this place was way better than joel robuchon.... I'll definitely come back for their empenadas :)
author: linda L.

description: Limon is one of our favorite restaurants in SF and we had our first visit since the fire last night.  The food is still excellent although the ceviche was not the stand out it once was.  Good but no longer great.  The steak and whole fried fish were superb.  Now the problem - the service is why the restaurant moved down from 4 stars to 3 stars.  When we arrived, there was no record of the reservation I made over the phone since they are not on Open Table.  It was early and not busy but we had long waits for drinks, more sauces and the check.  It was decidedly mediocre and a let down.  Still worth trying for the food  (great tasting/ good presentation) and atmosphere.
author: Celeste B.

description:
I have never tried Peruvian food, so upon trying Limon, I didn't really know what to expect. Although I didn't really have any expectations, I knew that Latin cuisine never fails, so somewhere in the back of my mind, I just knew Limon wouldn't fail. 

We started the night with drinks. I had the mango mojito and he had the regular mojito. Although the mojitos were sweet, we quickly caught on to the lack of alcohol. We were looking for something to hit us strong, but that mojito was definitely lacking. But we brushed it off because we knew there were plenty of bars around the area that we could hit up after dinner and probably would serve harder drinks for cheaper.

For starters, we shared the Limon-cebiche which had fish, calamari and shrimp. Now that cebiche was probably the best cebiche I've ever had. (ceviche? cebiche? I don't know? I always thought it was ceviche, until I read their menu.) I don't really know much about cebiche, but I'm glad we agreed on sharing one because I thought one cebiche plate would suffice as a whole meal for me. God, no. It's probably equivalent to a salad starter or something of that sort. 

I also love restaurants that serve free appetizers, like bread and butter. Limon is one of those restaurants (hell yes!) They serve bread along with two different sauces.
