The tres leches with ice cream was a tasty dessert, though I didn't have much of it after my large meal -- we ordered two appetizers and three entrees for three people.

The decor, noise-level, and layout were all welcoming and pleasant.  The space reminds me of Andalu, with a front dining room split with a bar, and a lofted space with another set of tables.
author: Jay M.

description:
If I had to choose one beverage to drink for the rest my life, it would be Limon's sangria.  Oh how fast I suck down those yummy concoction of chopped fruit marinated in velvety red...I've drank it so greedily on several occasions that my dining companion should have to know Heimlich maneuvers.  

When it's TOO busy, such as dinner rush hour, Thurs - Sat, it s annoying that there isn't ample space to wait, the seating will be cramped, and service can be truly south american style:  snail pace.  

But I've always been lucky, making to dinner either before or after the rush and always got sat right away.  

Must Try:  Anticucho de Pulpito...an octopus appetizer.  i won't recommend sharing .. unless they are willing to put out.  
Pargo Rojo, crispy whole red snapper.  I never order the same thing twice, but I make sure that SOMEONE at the table orders this dish.  The best part is the fried bones...savage~~~
author: Je C.

description:
Wow.

That was more or less the word of the evening in between pregnant pauses of awed silence that followed the arrival of each dish at this, what can only be referred to as an uber-restaurant.

As is modus operandi for me when I'm partaking in any kind of South American cuisine, Sangria was ordered before ass even touched cushion. While the Sangria was plentiful in a robust wine glass, it lacked a certain punch. I know this because whenever I get good and liquored up, I turn into my alter-ego, The Red-Faced Asian. He made no such appearance that night. Though I should point out that the drink was quite good and tasty, even if it wasn't potent.

Entrees were bucket-loads of incredible- my red snapper came delicately placed on the coiled skeleton of the poor fish that sacrificed itself for my pallet. Leslie had a slow-roasted chicken and as we ate and sampled each other's dishes the conversation slowly began to turn mono-syllabic as there's really nothing worthy of speaking about when you're eating food reserved for the gods.

As if that wasn't quite enough, there was dessert. Oh, god...there was dessert. A freshly baked mini-cake of chocolate with a gooey center of hot fudge agahghaghaghaghaghaghaghaghaghaghag...

I have to stop. i just can't...
author: keith k.

description:
Highly Overpriced... cold super fatty steak....  uncle Ben's minute rice

Very loud, slow service

If I want to eat cold food and scream at other people I'll goto a ball game.
author: John F.

description:
We had our company Sales dinner at Limon on a Thursday night. They smartly put us upstairs and we had a set menu--which usually annoys me, but not this time. They had a great selection of starters and entrees. I had the ceviche starter and the chicken main--oh yes and a chocolate something for dessert--it was delicious. 

We were a party of over twenty, service was great and timing was good. I think the prefixed menu was $40 a person and well worth it. Can't and won't really comment on the bar bill though...
author: Deborah S.

description:
I was really impressed when I left Limon for several reasons and the main one being the service, but I'll get to that in a minute.

We started with the Calamares Fritos (lightly breaded, crispy calamari with a chipotle aioli and sesame seeds  10.25) which was nice and not too oily. I've been dying to try their infamous Pargo Rojo (crispy whole red snapper basket, served with stir - fried coconut rice and rocoto curry sauce  27.95). The plating was beautiful, fun, and the red snapper was delicious. However, the red curry was a bit bland for my taste and the coconut rice had too much coconut I felt. But overall I was satisfied with what I had and didn't regret my choice. My bf ordered the Lomo Saltado (traditional peruvian dish of top sirloin slices sauteed with onions, tomatoes and fries, served with a side of rice 18.95). From the description we assumed the fries were going to be on the side, but it was mixed and cooked in with the whole dish! Awesome. Even better.

I noticed that everyone working here that night was male, latino/hispanic (i think), friendly, and very professional. Everyone had smiles on their faces and when the maitre d' brought us to our table he pulled out my chair AND my bf's chair! As well as laid down the napkins on our lap! We felt so undeserving. I can't count the number of times our glasses were refilled and our crums cleaned from the table. When tables were cleared for the next diners to arrive, the waiters would set down the table settings so precise and gentle, almost like he was about to be graded on his work. Watching the staff move around I noticed that everyone was pulling their weight evenly. No slackers. Everyone was on the same page. Just a group of hard workers. I admire that. I'm assuming that's one of the main reasons why Limon is so successful. 

Upon leaving we got the best thank you/come again/goodbye ever. Our waiter thanked us and said bye. Our bus boy thanked us and said goodbye. Two maitre d's thanked us a said goodbye. And the chef/owner thanked us and said goodbye too. I love how they make each person feel like they're the only diners in the restaurant. At least, that's how we felt. We had to leave 30% tip. It was definitely earned and deserved.

Overall, service outshined the food, even though the food was good. This restaurant is now one of my bf's favorite places to eat, and we definitely don't mind coming back. Limon is a good time.

Service: 5
Ambiance: 4.5 (it can get loud)
Food: 4
Overall: 4.5
author: Jen Y.

description:
We dropped by this place one afternoon wanting to try something new in the area. The place is very swank! Our waiter was super fun and chatted with us a bit as the place was not too busy during the day on a Saturday. We had a great bottle of wine and tasty food! Actually the food was way more than tasty, but I'm struggling at the moment for another adjective.
There were a bunch of larger groups having lunch and it seemed quite comfortable, but I can imagine the place to be a bit noisey if it were packed. I loved the layout and decor...oh and the food/wine (duh)! We had a great time.
author: Jocelyn J.

description: We got drunk on Pisco sours. They are dangerously delicious and addictive. Ceviche was perfectly balanced with flavors. Arroz con Mariscos was amazing paella.
author: Taylor C.

description: Limon is by far one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  I have been here a few times and tried a variety of things on the menu..I have never been disappointed with anything I have tried.  I ended up having one of my birthday gatherings here and they were able to work up a pre-fixe 3 course dinner menu for everyone, to make it easier for a large party.  The service is great, intimate space, clean bathrooms, super nice bartender guy and great fun location.
author: Helen C.

description:
Mr took me to Limon on a Saturday night. 

It took us awhile to find parking but it was worth it. I was a bit worried, 9:30 pm on Saturday night w/ no reservation, I wasn't sure if we can get seats. As Mr & I strolled inside, asked the hostess table for two, she promptly seats us by the table facing the st. It was lovely and bit romantic. Since I was craving Ceviches Mr ordered 4 different kinds of ceviches w/c by the way YUMMY. I find though that I like or prefer the traditional ceviches flavored w/ lemon than adding shi shi flavoring.

All in all...Mr & I had a great time.
author: jubi l.

description:
I've been loving Limon since they had the little place around the corner on 17th where they had seven tables and the area for the predictably long waits was the sidewalk. 

I love the new space too, but even more since my last experience there. My brothers and one of my brothers' girlfriend (she is ADORABLE!) were in town to celebrate Dia de los Muertos with us. We'd taken my carnivorous bros to Limon a while back and now it's always a mandatory stop whenever they visit. 

So this time we stop by before the DOD processional. Being the festive and wacky family we are, we HAD to dress up in full esqueleto regalia including face paint. We looked fabulous! I must admit. And since the procession started at 7pm, we had to be ready before dinner. Our skeleton family was welcomed with open arms and even accommodated with straws for our drinks so our make-up wouldn't smudge. We had a delightful meal of our favorites: ceviche, empanadas, lomo saltado, snapper, and mariscos. Plus a fab rioca!

Somehow the food tasted even better in a skeleton face. 

We left about 7:20pm (we knew it would start at 7pm, Latino time, so we were safe.) and as we stepped out into the lovely evening to greet and celebrate our ancestors, our painted-on smiles were even bigger!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Ceviche Limon=oh my!
Scallops with Foie Gras=sublime!
Chocolate Molten Cake=heaven!
Sangria=liquid ecstasy!
Handsome Peruvian Men who took great care of us=sigh...
author: Michelle S.

description:
very nice, chic spot.   started out here for happy hour, but then decided to to stay for dinner.

Happy Hour
* $2 peruvian beer, actually pretty decent
* $1 fresh oysters!  we had to order a minimum of 6, but it was definitely worth it; ended up doing 3 rounds!
* the chicharon de pollo was my favorite!  very well fried chicken thighs, with ceviche on top.  the chicken was prepared perfectly; the right amount of crispyness on the outside and tender & juicy on the inside.  the blend of soy sauce & garlic marinade definitely stood out.
* the portions were worth the price

Dinner
* ordered the arroz con mariscos.  this is a paella dish (peruvian style) that mixed together all kinds of seafood with rice.  because the portions were relatively huge during happy hour, i had the same expectations for dinner.  unfortunately, i was very disappointed as the portions were very small.  the rice wasn't prepared very well & i only had a few mussels & scallops.  definitely not like other peruvian places i've dined at.

definitely would recommend this place for happy hour, as a starter.  the menu was simple & delicious.  there is no full bar, so you are limited to the restaurant menu, in terms of alcoholic beverages.  i tried the limon mojito, which i was not a fan of.  

worth a try.
author: Ric A.

description: Incredible.  The sauces they give with the chicken are amazing.  Everything was good.  Lomo saltado, chicken, raw ahi, super good.
author: Sage S.

description: Truffle mac and cheese was amazing! Ceviches are some of my favorite in SF. Try one of their cocktails, I've enjoyed everyone I've tried so far.
author: Stacy W.

description:
Disappointing.  $60 pp of annoyance! we were nine people at 8pm and by 9.30 we asked how long until our entrees? another 30 mins.    some of our party had to leave early.  they screwed up the order...
my pork, bacon, cabbage, mushroom dish was good, but salty, i should have got a veggie side with it.  THe sole was delicious. The bit that got me was that there wasnt the slightest apology to placate us - "very busy tonight, sorry to keep you waiting, won't be much longer... blah blah blah" nothing.  At times like this you throw in another apetizer for free to keep us going right? i wont go back.
author: laura j.

description:
Never had a dinner here - just the rice pudding, which is the bomb.
Served warm , it is creamy and chock full of raisins, with a light sprinkle of cinnamon.  Oooh, so good.
author: Carla B.

description:
SOOOO DELICIOUS!!!

We had a super fantastic meal at Limon!  It was overly crowded, but show me a great spot in the Mission on a Friday night that's not!  We didn't care about standing in the doorway elbow to elbow with the fellow patrons waiting to be seated, cause we could tell just by watching the dishes passing by us that the food was gonna be gooooood...  And it was!  We must have each eaten a pound of squid (which I love!)...  we started with the calamari, which I usually avoid cause it's such a boring way to do squid, but this stuff was awesome!  We also started with ceviche mariscos in a creamy aji amarillo...  so good my belly is rumbling right now at just the thought!  Then we split the Lomo Saltado (delicious) and the Mariscos Picantes (also amazing!)...  we were so full by then that we didn't try dessert, but they looked beautiful and dangerously yummy! 

 And the service...  one of the best in the city!  My champagne flute was always full, plates were cleared immediately and the check was prompt upon request...  these guys were on it, without hovering or interrupting conversation.  The host and hostess were very friendly and made us feel important and welcomed.  And on our way out the door...  about ten staff members must have said good bye to us!  We will be back...  every night if I didn't have to work a few times a week.  My new favorite spot!  Go there now!

Limon is great!
author: Erica S.

description:
Limon is fantastic.  My girlfriends treated me to a bachelorette dinner party here and we enjoyed ourselves greatly!  We had:

Sangria: THE best I've had to date!

Calamares Fritos: perfection, not too greasy, not to dry, spicy.

Tatara de Atun: refreshing and spicy.

Pargo Rojo: delectable!

Arroz con Mariscos: The RICE...oh so good as was all of the seafood.

We also had a house special that evening of tamales verdes, which was also VERY GOOD! For dessert we topped off an evening of orgasmically good food with a volcanic explosion of chocolaty goodness that is the BANDIDO! All in all Limon is fantastic and I thank them for accomodating our late parties and not shooing us out too quickly.  This is a very popular restaurant and they most certainly can turn a table quickly, so they were very kind to us in letting us stay a while.  Thanks Limon, you're well worth your pennies in delicious food!
author: Devon P.

description:
Ola jefe! Es todo para los dollares del gringo, eh?

Yeah, yeah, I know... I spent 3 months in Peru, 6 weeks in Lima next to one of the best ceviche places in town, so I should try not to be too harsh. The ceviche at Limon is actually quite good if you stick to the traditional ones, either just with fish or with fish and seafood, but the sampler plate doesn't bring anything new and can be avoided.

No, the problem I have with Limon is that it feels like it's all about surfing the hype and squeezing as much money as possible out of the unsuspicious gringo. From that matter, they do bear their name well: step in there and you are guaranteed to feel their unique "Limon squeeze".

I went once already about 2 years ago. I found the check out of touch with the food they serve and I did not go back until the other day even though I live just around the block. This time around, all the prices had been jacked up to the point they're almost a joke.

The food itself, with the exception of a very correct ceviche, wasn't even that good. I ordered the scallops with foie-gras. Hey, I'm French, I wasn't going to miss out on that! I'll enjoy every bit of foie-gras before they make it illegal in California. Or so I thought... Small square plate, 2 scallops in opposite corners, 1 little coin-sized piece of foie-gras on top of each, a Jenna Jameson bush of greens in the middle... What the heck?! For 14 bucks, you could not have given me a decent serving?

Now about the taste... The cook slapped in it the delicacy of a Vegas surf-and-turf.  Instead of using a raw, pink, subtle, melting foie-gras, he took the gamey kind and overcooked it. Of course, it was a complete clash! So I ate the foie-gras with the fig sauce first, then the scallops totally on their own 'cause they wouldn't speak to the figs either.

Well well well. What's next? The cheapest dinner plate on the menu, the 22 bucks Picante de Mariscos. Not much to say on that one: mushy rice, heavy cream sauce, same taste across the entire dish. Is it a calamari I just put in my mouth or a piece of shrimp? A diced potato maybe? You get the picture.

The Parihuela and the red snapper were of the same vein: heavy-heavy and no love at all.

Finally, a little word about the drinks. Sometimes chefs who feel they can't live up to the hype have the wisdom to put one or two cheap drinks on the list, just to keep the patrons a bit loopy, focusing a bit more on the glass and a bit less on the plate. Not here. As for the rest, they don't care. They don't have to, the hype continues to draw the crowds. The cheapest glass of wine is at $10 and the rest... forget about it. They don't even offer a decent bottle at $30.

So what's left to say? When you're standing by the door, about to leave, the head waiter will bow obsequiously, exhibiting a large smile: "Thank you, sir, thank you!"... Well, I might have been screwed but at least it was with a smile. De nada, amigo. I'm glad you enjoyed it because it will be the last time.
author: Pierre S.

description:
Great atmosphere, wonderful service and superb ceviche.  HUGE fan of their aji amarillo ceviche.  I've had it with mixed seafood and with just shrimp.  I'd say that I preferred the just shrimp a tad bit better as the mixed seafood was mostly the corvina which was just okay.  Have ordered the lomo saltando twice now and will definitely order it again although the next time I go I've already decided to give their incredible looking snapper a try.  

Limon gets a 4.5 from me =)
author: shauna a.

description:
Had probably one of the subtlely worst service experiences in my life at Limon tonight. The staff never effed anything up but were the horrid combo of curt and pushy to the point of distracting from the excellent food. The worst part is that our server was being shadowed by a trainee who will carry this shitty attempt at service to your future.

We were constantly pushed to finish wine so as to be sold another carafe, nearly had a half finished plate of excellent ceviche taken from us by a busser who didn't understand our objections despite the fact that there was a ton of fish still on the plate and our forks were obviously still active. I understand the desire to move courses along but expect communication and intelligence to win out over bs orders to move customers along. I also understand the desire to sell, but a place such as Limon should have servers talented enough to sell suggestively or to recognize a table where 'selling' is inappropriate.
Your staff failed so miserably in these aspects that despite no adverse service eff-ups my party felt crowded and rudely treated. Unacceptable.

PS -- also caught your floor mgr on cell phone blocking access to bathroom hallway, hostess on cell phone at front host stand. The perfect compliment to uninformed/poorly executed table service.

Also, I am a lifelong restaurant worker/business owner/manager. Not a novice. I never send complaints like this, however, tonight's experience sits so poorly in my memory when compared with the excellent food quality that I felt it was worth mentioning.
author: Giants C.

description: Good service. Good pisco sour. My friends chicken was solid. Paella was crap. For 20$ should have more than two shrimp, clam, and mussels. Extremely small portions and low quality for the price. If you want paella go to a Spanish restaurant or make it at home. Another SF trap on Valencia.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Limon has currently won my heart and the top spot on my list for SF dining. It is a fun atmosphere for groups and dates alike and the food is consistently fantastic.

Without a doubt, start with one of Limon's many many ceviche options. I prefer the creamy shrimp vegetable sauce with shrimp (shrimp on shrimp). The shrimpies are huge and the taste is delightful. 

The menu provides various Peruvian options, but don't shy away because you aren't sure what Peruvian food really is. The food is not overly ethnic, there are seafood dishes very similar to paella (Arroz con Mariscos) and a grilled sirloin with french fries dish  (Lomo Saltodo) you can't find elsewhere. Also, if you dare, they serve a crispy snapper with the head smiling up at you from your plate. The coconut cake dessert with sorbet is a perfect finishing touch. 

The best thing about Limon is the decor (colorful) and the atmosphere (lively). Some complain about the noise level but on a weekend night before I hit the town, I appreciate that energy. One last thing you can't miss-- Limon's sangria. A perfect blend. Cheers to good times and good food at Limon!!
author: Haley M.

description: fancy, a bit dark inside, lots of action going on, the chicken was delicious, we sat at the bar, didn't have much time but they were very accommodating despite the fact that we didn't have much time to eat. even though we only a had about 20 minutes it felt like time slowed down as we savored each bit of veggies and roasted chicken. yummmm
author: Al B.

description: Celebrated a friend's birthday here.  Good spot!  Service was excellent and the food very tasty.  My Pollo Latino was well presented and put together very agreeable flavors although the chicken itself was not evenly cooked.  The mac and cheese with it was crazy good and the chocolate tres leches cake was a winner.  Another place that gets very loud but other than that YUP - I say do it!  I'll try the ceviche next time.
author: Julienne G.

description: Came here back in January of 2004 and thought the food was alright but not as good as fresca.  I had the Lomo Saltado but I came out feeling kind of hungry still.  Thoughts of heading down the block for a burrito crossed my mind but their sangria held me thru.  We sat on the second level and the noise level with a bit high if you want a descent conversation without saying, 'huh'?
author: Max L.

description: My review is based off only trying the ceviche limon and sangria but those two dishes alone compelled me to write a passionate 5 star review!  Came with with a group of friends on a weekend trip to SF upon their recomendation. I am not  familiar with Peruvian food but I am definitely becoming a fan.  The citrus chili marinade called leche de Tigre is just mouthwateringly flavorful.  And the quality of the seafood is sooooo fresh and decadent!  It's not cheapest eats but I will splurge on this anytime. I am already craving it as I head home to San Diego!!!
author: Stephanie O.

description: I've been going to Limon Rotissierie for lunch with my co-worker as a treat every so often and I love it their food - so I wanted to make the comparison between the two since I've heard so many rave reviews about Limon. So I met up with a friend for Happy Hour...and it IS as fabulous as  Limon Rotissierie...if not better!  $1.00 Oysters,  Ceviche Shooters (a litte salty but still good!), sweet  potato fries, and of course, the SANGRIA...I can't say enough about the Sangria...one fo the best I've ever had in this area.  This is definitely my go-to place that I would take people who are visiting in the area...or just to sit back and relax with good friends and enjoy a glass of Sangria.    The service was great, they were constantly checking up on us and refilling our glasses.  The only drawback...parking is tough to come by, but well worth the time and the walk.
author: Michelle F.

description: LOVE. Excellent plates: ceviche limon, jalea, chicharones de pollo, and short rib. The profiteroles were outstanding and caught us off-guard. Lively atmosphere. The only quibble is that the tables (I noticed others in addition to myself struggling with this) are cheap, wobbly and not attached to bases but rather spin like records! Cheesy! Get better tables, Limon! But the food was so awesome that I can't possibly hold it against. I'd eat out of my lap in the toilet stall for food this good.
author: O. K.

description:
Ceviche and Sangria. 

We came here on a Saturday afternoon with a NY friend. All of the cuisine was fresh, delicious, succulent. And reasonably-priced: Ceviche - we had two orders - and Sangria - we had two pitchers (there were three of us now). Our waiter was sincere. He recommended for dessert the warm fresh chocolate souffle cake - we ordered two, which were heavenly. 

Ordering two of everything here worked really really well.
author: Holly F.

description:
I finally did it! I ate at Limon! 

Wow...the food was good. I would highly recommend the Empanada Don Walter (the cream sauce is to DIE for) and the Tatara de Atun for appetizers (peppers, pears, and nuts set it apart). The ceviche was OK. It didn't blow me out of the water and I thought there was little in the traditional ceviche offerings since that is what everyone raves about. I ordered the chicken infused with mac and cheese for my main sha bang which was great, but a bit rich after so many starters. 

I would come prepared for a big meal (the entrees take quite a while to cook and the whole experience is set up to enjoy appetizers and ceviche). The wait staff is gorgeous and very accommodating so take advantage and ask suggestions.
author: Alicia J.

description:
This used to be one of our favorite spot for some great food.  Unfortunately the quality of the food has gone down significantly.  Three of us who were fans of Limon recently went to there for dinner.  After dinner, all of us agreed that we would not be back any time soon.  

I really hope that something changes because we really did love this place.  The problems we had with the food were too much salt in the steak medallions and the snapper was under-cooked and there was barely any meat on the fish.  The hostess was a bit unprofessional as well.  She didn't take us to our table, rather she pointed to the corner table and told us where our table was.
author: Matt L.

description:
A mouthwatering restaurant that's best to reserve ahead of time.   

Upon entering, my friends and I didn't have to wait  long to be seated which was nice.  Perhaps it was the late reservation of 9pm that helped pave the way.  Whatever the case, once we had our place, the service was prompt and professional.  Drinks and appetizers were ordered and off they went. All the more better because we were starving.  

Plated in an eye pleasing manner, I had no trouble diving right in and destroying the presentation.   Among the appetizers - baby octopus, crispy calamari, marinated chicken - I thought their ahi tuna was the best, fresh with a spicy kick.  

The sangria was overly sweet, and after awhile started to taste like fruit punch.  Not the best I've ever had, but by the third or fourth pitcher, it begins to grow on you.  I would have settled for a nice bottle of wine instead given the food pairing.

For my main entree, I had what I believed to be the pork loin.  It was cooked to perfection, the white meat tender without a hint of dryness. 

The portions in relation to the price is reasonable.  For a nuevo latino fusion restaurant, it's a definite winner.
author: Baldwin H.

description:
Hi i Just want to thank you guys for make my mom so happy on her bday. we went to limon on saturday brunch, we get the groupon, but i decided to make a reservation at 1 anyway. We arrive like 10 min before 1, and they told us that we have to wait for around 15 min, fear enough, for the 10 min earlier. The hostes ask us if we want to wait by the bar, so we did take the offer. the wait was around 20 min, but u can see that the restaurant was so full. the bartender serve us some drinks to make our wait more comfortable. lunch was great, the food as good as always, i love the ceviche limon, have that taste that is no easy to describe, the shoters were great (believe me you have to try the oyster one), we got same veggie empanadas, and the parihuela so good...
definetly I recomend this place and i will always keep going back!!!!!
thanks
Vanessa
author: Vanessa P.

description:
Came here for my friend's birthday with a group of 20+ people. We had a reservation but didn't get seated for quite some time.

Our service was okay. Not bad, but very forgettable.

Other than that, they have a great prix fixe for a really good price. Pitchers of sangria really add up. Vegetarian entree was bland.
author: Sheena M.

description:
I'm not one of those people who go to a nice restaurant and orders chicken.  But for some reason I did it at Limon.  We waited hours (literally...if you have a big group, they ask you to come late and then you wait and wait and drink and drink).  I ordered the Chicken Latino.  It may be called pollo.  Anyway, this chicken was heavenly and I don't even really care for chicken much.  I can't even describe it.  It was tender and flavorful with a crispy outside. It came with truffle mashed potatoes.   It was perfection. The waiter even commented, "wasn't it worth the wait?"  and it was.  This review is based only on the chicken. I had ceviche and some other appetizer and they were nice.  I tasted someone's steak and it was a'ight.  They should have ordered the chicken!

Eat the chicken.  Please.  You'll thank me later.
author: Emily G.

description:
I've heard some great things about this place, and I'd sampled the food as they provided a bit of ceviche at an event.  So...here's my take now that I've been there.  They make great food.  The marinade for their ceviche was great, and the empanadas were a touch olive heavy, but very tasty.  The mussel appetizer was phenomenal.  Sweet, succulent mussels, and the bacon....(insert Homer Simpson sounding aaaahh) so good.  They also make a killer truffled mac and cheese.  I also had a great sangria, and my fella had a very good Belgian beer. 

My only issue was the service.  It was slow, we had to ask several times for the status of food, and watched people get served around us and head out the door before we got our second appetizers.
author: Erin O.

description:
4 Stars

This place is fancy smancy. Good place to go on a date or to impress someone. The ambiance is romantic and has lots of candles.  I like how the menu is simple, not too many choices. Just simple good ones. I highly recommend getting a pitcher of sangria to accompany your dinner. The fruits are cut really small and cute (it just taste better when it's cute!) Pair this with Ceviche Limon and Choros a la Criolla. Very yummy!
author: Elaine T.

description:
I wish my taste buds had fingers so they can type this review!

My friend recommended this place.  He said it's probably the best peruvian food he's ever had. Which is pretty bold considering he's been to peru a few times.

I absolutely agree. I will rate everything I ordered:
-Cau cau de mariscos: A delicious soup like mix of clams, mushrooms, fish, and other stuff...  What i love about this plate is the lack of that fishy taste or smell.  I abhor anything fishy.  So I was impressed with this dish.
-Chicharron de Pollo: normally chicharron is a style of pork thats been deep fried in such a way that it's crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. Like biting into a creme puff (sorta).  But traditionally they do this with pork... how Limon managed to do this with chicken really boggle my mind.  So good. Salty and crispy on the outside... tangy and soft as you chew.  it burst in your mouth with flavor.
-Empanadas:  Pretty popular in south america. the dough was flavorful and the stuffin out of this world.  I dipped it in the sauce that accompanies the dish.  Good with or without. 
-Churrasco a la parrilla:  A grilled ribeye, the kind you eat on a sunday with friends accompanied by mexican beer!  very tasty. The seasoning really gave it a zesty kick of flavor as i bit into it.  i loved it.
-Lomo saltado: this by far was my favorite dish here.  And pretty much the best lomo saltado I've had anywhere.  ANYWHERE.  The meat was well done but still tender.  The tomatoes and fries. with rice... wow.  So many different taste and textures.  Amazing.
-Sangria:  I've had  enough sangrias in my day to judge a good sangria from bad and let me tell you: the sangria here is probably among the top 3 sangria i've ever had.  It was silky.  with a sweet flavor.  You can tell they used a decent bottle of wine: maybe cuz frisco is so close to napa. I dunno. but we were really impressed. The fruits in it were fresh. They didn't have the old lazy pruney look that i've seen in some sangrias.  I even tasted ginger!  very good stuff indeed.

As far as decor, its very modern, the seats were a bit uncomfortable. The bar looked nice. The staff was extremely courteous and attentive. My water glass was never half less than half full.  And when we ordered our sangria pitcher they were always there to top us off.

Overall I was impressed and very pleased with my experience at Limon. I definitely recommend this place to anyone and will be back the next time I visit the bay.
author: Samuel C.

description: DELICIOUS food. Very tasty no doubt. A little bit pricey but that's what you get for quality food, service, and nice ambiance. I checked in and got a free sangria which was awesome. Then we shared all three of the ceviche's and they were TASTY! Then I got the Lomito Soltado which was so good I cleaned the plate. My friends got the rib eye steaks which were also amazing. i will def. be back here. Only problem is parking, I wish more places in SF did valet. I had to park on the street which took a good 10 minutes and 4 block walk.
author: Alex Y.

description:
I love nuevo latino spots like this.

The empanadas, sangria and decor make for a good time.

Only thing is you better like salt.  You can't avoid it on most dishes.  I even felt like a deer at a salt lick eating the salad.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
OK, I wasn't expecting the ceviche to be a meal unto itself, but the Ceviche Limon is this tower of seafood, not some diced up fish bits in lime juice.  Big chunks of halibut, prawns, octopus, and other garnish, flanked by two mussels and a smattering of Peruvian corn.  Totally "mmmmgasmic".

I also tried the Pollo Latino which turned out to be a tad on the salty side, but the sauce was concentrated with such flavor and punch that the saltiness didn't matter.  I couldn't honestly say that I tasted the truffles in the mash, but it was very good nonetheless.  Very good.

I've heard that this place is really loud at times almost to the point of not being able to hear the person sitting right next to you, but maybe I went on a night where it was a little less crowded.  Definitely make reservations before you go.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
Yum.  Ceviche y sangria.  No liquor, though.

If I had to be more critical, I'd comment that the halibut in the ceviche seemed especially chewey.  And the sangria was a wee bit too sweet.  And our soup (roasted red pepper and tomato) seemed straight out of a can of Campbell's (good thing I'm OK with Campbell's soup).  

But I'd return in a heartbeat...
author: S J.

description:
Too much atmosphere to make up of so-so food.  
If you really know about south american / peruvian food, you know that's not what they serve in Limon.  
I'm not saying they serve bad food, but that's just not peruvian.  And please don't call it fusion either.
author: N. C.

description:
Arrived there about 8pm on a Sat. night. It wasn't overly crowded. 

I love to cook, so I was expecting a lot of flavor - especially since this  is a Peruvian Restuarant.

We ordered about 6 appetizers: Ensalada Mixta, Soup, Fried Calamari, Empanadas, Ceviche, and Foie Gras.

The salad was pretty good, but mostly greens
lentil soup was perfect
fried calamari was below average- not too much taste and slightly overcooked
empanadas were delicious but a little cold
ceviche was very good, but extremely tiny portions
the foie gras was very good, but the portion was tiny (nice sized scallops though)

I ordered the Fried Red Snapper and it seemed overcooked and under-seasoned. The coconut curry sauce that accompanied it was very tasty. The rice that came with the snapper seemed like it was slightly too busy with ingrediants, but very tasty.

I was a little dispappointed in the service as our waitress seemed a little annoyed with us as we were a party of 6 and sometimes took a few extra moments to figure out what we wanted. We ordered  a bunch of appetizers so we could share and taste a few things.

Dessert was satisfying. We ordered the tres de leche cake, flourless choc. cake, and bread pudding. Each was quite scrumptuous. The bread pudding seemed a little cold, though.

Overall, I would go there again if my friends suggested it, but my husband and I would not go there on our own.
author: Jackie S.

description:
I work nights/weekends so the only upside is that I luck out with hardly ever having to wait for a table on my days off. And dinner at Limon was no exception. Now to the food:
 
(Appetizer) Calamares Frites - pretty good, tasty salsa dip, but doesn't top the ones at Butterfly
(Me) Churrasco a la Parilla: meat was nice and tender; sides were so-so. Sadly I wasn't that hungry that night, but my boyfriend enjoyed finishing the plate for me. 
(Him) Picante de Mariscos: it was a paella-like dish, and i thought it was so-so. 

I really liked the ambiance - and would love to come back with a group of friends.
author: Janet P.

description:
I had promised myself that I wouldn't write another yelp review until I have something positive to say.  As you can see, I haven't written a review in a while....since then I have received a BAD haircut (disguised as a good one for a few days), had to deal with VERY bad service with COMCAST and AT & T wireless AND had dinner at Limon.  I can't hold back anymore!

Don't waste your money here.  One star for service and one star for the space which I must say was the high point for Limon....open kitchen, lime colored walls with orange, stainless, brown wood and slate accents.  Great lighting and floral accents.

Ceviche de Corvina: this was given NO love...kept having to pull the sinew out of each piece as it was BUTCHERED TO DEATH.

Empanada Don Walter: OK.  I recommend Inkas in Bernal Heights over these.

Vieres con Foie: seared scallops and foie gras...two bite sized scallops with a sliver of over-seared foie.  Definitely nothing to write home about.

Chicarron de Pollo: this was just a bad choice.  I don't know why we ever ask for a recommendation from the server.  This was the case.  Again, bad choice.

Decided against ordering a main course which could have been a mistake.  We didn't risk it.

BIG MISTAKE NUMBER ????  We ordered dessert!  Carrot and raisin cake at the advice of our server (hubby's choice) $9 later.  Add to that a horrible double cappuccino for $5.

Bill total:  $85.  This was a bit of a shock.  We  had intended to go get a small and quick bite to eat (which we never do).  We also added a veg plate (which was seasoned well and cooked properly) and a glass of Albarino...crisp, clean and delicious.

This is strike two out of three Peruvian restaurants.  I'm going back to Inkas next time!

Over and out.
author: Sandy K.

description:
This is my happy place. Best sangria, best food love this place.
The sweet potatoes are amazing!! I crave this place all the time, so I make it a point to come here at least once a month. the staff is hit or miss -sometimes nice but mostly too busy to give you real customer service. But it doesnt effect the experience much bc the food is so delicious -anything on the menu is great never have tried a bad thing!
author: Jasmin L.

description: We recently went to Limon to help celebrate my and my sister in law's birthdays.  We had a fairly big group - about 20 ppl.  The experience was largely positive.  We all opted to go the prix fixe menu for the ease of ordering and found that it is WAAAY too much food.  If you're going to do that, order a bit less.  It's family style so you can make it stretch.  If I could go back, I'd do maybe 15 or 16 ppl's worth, and order any other little side plates.  Better, I'd suggest to Limon to lessen the amount of food and bring the price down a bit.  That might be more appropriate.  It was also a bit crowded, but since our group rocked, we didn't mind as much.  Still it's always nice to be able to move around and not make the entire table get up if someone has to go to the bathroom.  Regardless, the food was pretty good, drinks went down easily, and a good time was had by all.
author: Sandy B.

description: I echo the other reviews here regarding going with a group.  We had a group of ten; they wouldn't seat us until we were all there, we had to order from their prix fixe menu which didn't offer a lot of choices, the waiter made us feel as if they were doing us a favor by serving us, and about two hours after the time of our reservation, we were finishing up our meal, and the waiter came over and said, "You know you have to leave at 7:30, right?" Apparently, there's a time limit on tables, and they took the food off our table in order to rush us out.  Mind, we spent probably six hundred dollars at this place between drinks and food. The only reason I gave it as many as two stars is because the food was good. I rarely write bad reviews, but Limon needs to get over itself.
author: Robbie K.

description: I am going to make this simple, great chicken, decent prices ,  and cozy atmosphere.
author: Sulaiman B.

description:
YUUUUMMMY!
 You must have at least one pitcher of $30 sangria, yes pricey but well worth it! We went through 4! The ceviche was very fresh and perfectly portioned. The steak was excellent and snapper even better. Tried all three deserts sooo good.  I didn't have to pay, even better.
author: Douggers M.

description:
A friend took me out to dinner here.  Certainly pricey, but also exquisite food and fantastic service.  

And vegetarians, don't be deterred by the fact that there is only one vegetarian entree.  I had the veggie plate and it was superb - a rice dish with vegetables (and possibly some kind of cheese).  I'm making it sound plain, but it was as far from plain as you can imagine.  They are clearly big on presentation here.  My friend ordered one of the seafood dishes (they have mostly seafood dishes) and loved it.  We split a salad which was also lovely and tasty.  

Limon is certainly buzzing on its own hype but they do offer great service, stylish presentation, and some unique and mouth-watering flavor combinations.  

My one critique is that the place is rather loud and crowded.  They have packed the tables in too close together: it isn't physically uncomfortable but you will have a hard time hearing a person even a foot away from you.  If it were a little less loud, it would be a much better setting for a romantic dinner.
author: Ann S.

description:
Bad reviews for this place complain about wait time for service, but they all say the food is good.  Personally I think a longer dinner with drinks, good conversation and even better food is the epitome of a perfect meal, but I guess everyone is different.

Minus 1 star because the entrees weren't 5 star.  The ceviche and scallops w/ foie gras were on point.

We had:
- Sangria (a bit too sweet for me)
- Scallops & foie gras (you get 2, but they're oh so buttery smooth)
- Ceviche Limon (kick ass medley of seafood & citrus)
- Pargo rojo (not bad)
- Neiman ranch pork chop (not bad)
- Bread pudding w/ coconut ice cream (can't go wrong w/ bread pudding)

No pics this time ... sorry.  I was on a hot date.
author: James F.

description:
Maybe my expectations were too high, but I felt this place was a little disappointing. There were some pros, we got a great seat on the balcony overlooking the restaurant. The sangria was very good, and I liked the empanadas and chicken small plate, however, the thing I had been most excited, the ceviche, was just ok. Isn't that what they are known for? The calamari in the ceviche was soooooo chewy and the fish was a little too fatty, also hard to chew. I may go back to get apps and sangria, but I would skip the ceviche.
I have had much better elsewhere.
author: Adrienne G.

description: I remember celebrating my birthday here 5 years ago & when I went back it didn't seem the same.  The food wasn't as great as I had remembered.  They offer $1 oysters for happy hour, but not on fridays & weekends.  The ceviche was okay, a little tough on some of the seafood.  The mariscos was pretty good.
author: Jo B.

description: Liked the food, the service was okay.  The artwork really dominates the space.  Great for sharing, especially the sangrias.  The modern feel is cool, but a bit much.  The best dishes are the steak and tuna plates.  The people who come here are usually wearing black and look like they just came from the W.
author: Christian M.

description: I wanted to love it as much as Limon Rotisserie, but something was different. Oh yah, the prices. It's slightly more upscale, but I would walk 7 blocks more for the sister restaurant.
author: johanna a.

description:
I have a friend originally from Peru and he took us here for dinner.    He ordered for us and loved all the great dishes they have.   We had the ceviche, the chilean sea bass, baby octopus and couple of meaty dish.  

Parking is a bit challenging in this area and obviously this is a happening place ...
author: Christopher T.

description:
Had my birthday dinner there this evening. The food was wonderful, full of flavor. It does get pretty crowded so make sure you have reservations as I saw a lot people turned away due to a full house.

Great place to bring friends and relatives from out of town!
author: umeboshi l.

description:
I liked the Sangria and the truffle-infused mushrooms the best. When I come back here again I will definitely order those again.

The top sirloin dish tasted like a chinese beef over rice dish.

The red snapper was very artfully presented and quite yummy. I didn't care for the rice that came with it though.

The empanadas were very good, though kind of pricey.

The ceviche is pretty good. I definitely prefered the mixed seafood ceviche over the shrimp ceviche.

The ambiance and service is also very modern and a great place for a date or gathering of friends and/or family.
author: Margaret W.

description:
This is definitely a splurge for us, but man oh man it's good. I've been twice and haven't been disappointed. The service staff really seems to know their stuff and are quite attentive. The ceviches are, of course, the best you'll have outside of, perhaps, South America. 

Definitely try to get reservations for parties of 3 or more though, and I think the seats/tables upstairs might be the tragic side of the restaurant.

They have a great white wine from New Zealand, can't remember the name though.
author: Tyler M.

description:
Wow.  Limon was *that* good.  Even the tangy little sauce that came with the bread was impressive.

We started out with the ceviche de corvina con camaron, which was very nice, delicate and refreshing.  The Peruvian corn reminded me of my trip to Peru where I decided I needed to be adventurous and sample the local fare.  So, I ordered cuy, which turned out to be a flattened, fried guinea pig accompanied by potatoes and corn.  Imagine a guinea pig, with its little rodent face with big teeth and little tiny legs with sharp claws all dead atop a pile of potatoes and big corn kernels.  Yes, it tasted like chicken.

But I digress.  My pork chop was absolutely delicious - possibly the best I've had in the city.  I really enjoyed the mushroom, bacon, potato complement.  Probably because it included bacon.

My dining companion ordered the roasted chicken breast, enticed by the promise of truffle-infused mac & cheese.  He enjoyed the chicken.  I enjoyed the truffle-infused mac & cheese, which reminded me of a wedding I attended where I chased down the servers who were passing around little ramekins of truffle-infused mac & cheese.  But again, I digress.

I can't believe it's taken me so long to dine at Limon.  I shall return!
author: Marcus C.

description:
A very old friend and I got reacquainted at Limon Friday night over an amazing meal of Ceviche en Crema de Aji Amarillo, Calamares Fritos, Mariscos con Arroz, and Pescado Frito. Everything was fresh and perfectly prepared. Not only was the presentation of the fried snapper truly artful, my first bite took me to another place. A wonderful place of tender and crisp and salt and pepper and other things that words cannot describe. The ceviche with cream sauce also blew all other ceviches out of the water. 

We had too much food for two people which I regretted when the dessert menu came around and I could only imagine how good the chocolate bandido cake would have tasted. 

This was my second visit to Limon, and the service was top notch once again.
author: Joanna W.

description:
Even though talking too much about the great Peruvian food you had the other night can make you sound like a bit of a ethnic-hipster poser, this place is really a gem.

Excellent service, very stylish, and a unique menu that includes many civiche varieties and plenty of red meat.
author: C P.

description:
I came with a large group and we each had a different impression of the restaurant based on what we ordered for our main entree, an indication that the food is not of consistent quality across the board. 

The Churrasco a la parilla (grilled ribeye), we all agreed, was the best thing on the menu. Cooked to absolute perfection. The Aroz con Mariscos (Peruvian style paella) also got rave reviews from our group. The Chuleton Carlitos (pan roasted pork chop) and Pollo Latino (pan roasted chicken breast) got somewhat less sparkling reviews -- the pork chop was said to be too salty and the chicken on the dry/bland side. 

You must try the Panna Cotta de Mango for dessert... A.M.A.Z.I.N.G. 
Even the toughest critic in our group was wowed by it. 

What I didn't like about this place was the really shady neighborhood it was in (didn't feel safe at all), and the difficulty finding parking. I recommend parking in the Hoff St. Garage. It's only 1 block away. We were there for 2 hr 45 min and it only cost $7.50. Beats circling the sketchy neighborhood searching for street parking.
author: C. J.

description: I was a longtime customer at 1001 South Van Ness until I had several rude experiences there by Gabby and the recent spate of waiters who don't care about their customers. I will only patronize this location from now on. I had three dinners here that were great and the wait staff was awesome. Concerning my earlier complaint I find it interesting that Larina the Business Manager for the company never returned my calls or responded to my complaints about 1001 So. Van Ness. It's okay Laurina. You obviously pick and choose for whatever reason. Just know this...I spend about $1,000 a year at your restaurant. Just think if you treated me in the same manner to 100 customers how much your owner would like that type of customer service. Seems like you learned from your crappy staff at South Van Ness. Message to owners: write me anytime and I will vent a bit, but tell you the truth about what is really going on at So. Van Ness. Still love your food tremendously! Thank you!
author: Tim H.

description: My all time favorite Peruvian restaurant! Great place to come with friends or a date. Absolutely love the ceviche de camaron y pescado, yuka, lomo salado. You really can't go wrong with any seafood dish. They also have delicious drinks mango mojitos, pisco sour and my favorite the sangria. Gets pretty busy on weekends and parking is hard to find. I believe they still take reservations still best to come early due to parking.
author: Lydia C.

description:
Food was good.

For apps we ordered the baby octopus, empanadas and pollo.  The octopus was ehh (which i caught some flack for cause I insisted on ordering it instead of the always popular but boring calamari)  and the empanadas were more ehhh, but the pollo was very tasty. 

Sangria was very sweet but maybe a little too sweet. 

Ordered the red snapper which was beautifully plated and had good flavor but it didnt match the expectations I had once I set my eyes upon the edible artwork.  

Just like this review, Limon is substantial but very easily forgotten.
author: Hansen S.

description:
I likewise heard great things about this place.  My brother dragged me along because of the buzz he had heard about this place.

Yeah, the food was good but definitely not worth all the buzz.
author: Rene M.

description: Staff are all very friendly and attentive.  My peruvian stir fry was excellent, however my dining partner's battered deep fried prawns came with their shells on.  Think about that.  How are you suppose to eat deep fried anything with a shell on.  Did they de-vein the critter or just dump it in the batter and fry it?  We asked the server and he said it was the "latest way of doing it".  It sounds like the laziest way of doing it and totally unbelievable. Deserts were delicious, but this prawn thing has me really scratching my head.  The latest way?
author: William G.

description:
I loved this place! It's a bit small so I can see how people would hate the wait, it's bound to be expected in a smaller joint with good food. Just make reservations! My friend and I did and we actually got seated early.

We started off with pisco sours and ceviche.....YUM!! The ceviche was the combo one with all sorts of goodies in there. I was especially surprised by the tenderness of the squid, I had never had it like this before and I can say it's now my favorite. The drinks were strong - a little pricey but super good. 

The food here comes family style but not in the way that I traditionally think of family style. I think family style like Italian food where there's a giant platter and everyone can dig in. In fact the food is perfectly paired for two people to share, great for a date but not as a family otherwise you have to order a lot more dishes. For instance we ordered the empenadas and the plate came with two. Not great for a family but for a date it worked out perfectly because we didn't have to fight over anything.

The quality and taste of the food was terrific. I've only ever had empenadas homemade from a Latina woman at the farmers market so I'm spoiled, but this gave her a run for her money! We had the pollo ones with capers and hard boiled eggs. We also had the beef (rib meat I think) and as I tried to pick it up and put it on my plate, the meat literally fell apart. It was THAT tender! So we just ate it off the serving plate. It was like a potroast with the usual veggies but the spices were different. 

Oh we also had the sweet potato fries - didn't really "go" with the other two dishes but they sounded too good to pass up and they were definitely worth fighting over.

I would happily go again for a date. Not as a group or as a family because I can see the bill getting racked up really easily, but for two or maybe four people I would happy eat again!
author: Ariel G.

description:
I was in Peru for a few weeks earlier this year.  Limon didn't strike me as particularly Peruvian, but as the other reviews attest, the food is very very good.  

We arrived 20 minutes early for a 9:30 reservation and the hostess was so happy that we had a reservation that she found a table for us immediately.
author: T H.

description:
More alcohol please!

I celebrated my birthday here recently, and really enjoyed this fine Mission establishment. The Ceviche de Pescado was spicy and flavorful, although the halibut actually toughened up a bit in the process. Despite the sheer volume of Empanadas appetizers that were blowing through the kitchen, ours arrived needing 30 seconds more in the fryer to crisp up. Finally, the Sangria consisted of about 90% ice and fruit, 10% delicious ambrosia. We ordered another though, politely asking for more alcohol.

These minor inconveniences were more than made up for in the absolutely delicious Lomo Saltodo and starter salad. It was a touch loud, but I enjoyed the ambience. It looked like a great place to bring a larger group - there were a few tables upstairs that could accommodate 8+.
author: Andy T.

description:
I don't now much about Peruvian food, but I do know this place is great.  My co-worker's wife, who is from Peru, considers the food very authentic.  Ceviches & calamari are Great!  Prices are a bit expensive for the portions, but you really have to appreciate the flavor(s) of the dishes.  Some of them are very much worth it!  

Peruvian beer is OK...they have some good Peruvian tropical drinks that I see people order.  Try the Yellow Cola (yes, yellow cola), it tastes a little weird, but if nothing else,  it's worth ordering just for the color!
author: D C.

description:
Limon is probably as close to 5 star as you get in my book while still being decidedly 4 star.  Service is very good and they are always accommodating when I am with people without a reservation (warning -- my girlfriend knows some of the waiters and I think we get special treatment).  The ambiance is very good and I love the story behind the place: a few authentic Peruvian brothers bootstrapped their way up the restaurant food chain until they finally set up this hip Mission restaurant after smaller digs elsewhere.  

The food: good authentic Peruvian food without a true standout.  The ceviche is very good and the Steak with fries over rice is a meat and carb lovers dream.  The tuna tartare and Pollo loco are great but clear Aqua knock offs that unfortunately are not as good as the real thing.  The red sangria is very good and the sorbets are a great finisher.  Overall the main problem is that the food is slightly hit or miss, especially from night to night.  

Still, great for a date or dinner with friends or having some fries at the bar with a cold Peruvian beer.  Definitely worth working into your Mission restaurant rotations.
author: Max V.

description:
First time, excellent experience with a nice and hip atmosphere, out-the-world ceviche . 
Second time, passable halibut ceviche, forgettable main courses(actually my husband was kind enough to switch with me after i put down my fork after two bites). His was better but not by much. 
Hmm let me try to remember what I got .
author: parmesa h.

description: Came here with a big group of girls and had a blast! When we got there, our reservation was not ready, and was postponed for quite a while. HOWEVER, the staff and manager did such an amazing job and making up for it! We got free appetizers while we waited, and once we were seated the manager came over with some delicious shots and took one with us. The food was absolutely amazing. One of the best ceviches I have ever had! Definitely would recommend this place!
author: Meagan B.

description: Was very surprised this place didn't get a better review. Food was excellent. Empanadas amazing. Best part- didn't have to wait for seating on a Friday night in the mission.
author: L P.

description:
Ceviche was pretty good. Rib eye was way over salted. Red Snapper was served, "fish nuggets "style. Service was mediocre. Hopefully, they will get the kinks worked out soon. 

Overall...Meh.
author: Brett M.

description:
Thanks to yelp we ordered the Mixed ceviche: really good and there's a hint of zest in it. I would definitely recommend this dish.  I think one can never fail with a chicharon, it was crunchy, oily, and oh so good. The sauce that came with it was a mixture of lemon and some spices and it worked really well with the meat.  There were three of us but they only serve 2 empanadas per dish. A bit disappointed with the portions, we shared the dish equally. Unfortunately, the empanada didn't live up to my expectations. Yes the meat was quite tasty yet there was something missing, like a "ummph" in a dish. I couldn't tase the raisin that was said to be included in the empanada and I wish there were more ingredients in it other than the beef. Last thing we ordered was the rotisserie chicken which was a miss! Unfortunately, the chicken was too salty that by the end of the night, my tongue felt grated. Eating the chicken became annoying because I felt my tongue drying out... The ambiance downstairs made up for their misses since the downstairs area looked hip with the couches, the low table, a lot of open space, and a bar at the bottom.

Would have given it a four star if it wasn't for three things: the salty chicken, the long wait, half an hour to be exact with RESERVATIONS, and the watered down sangria.
author: Anette N.

description: Went there last Tuesday night for date night with my girlfriend.  We got there around 5:30 and it was already busy.  We were greeted by friendly hostess and server.  Ordered wine and chicken and tuna with veggie sides.  Everything was delicious and the prices were affordable.  The restaurant filled up quickly.  We were very happy with the service and food.  Will definitely go back!!
author: Jenny H.

description: Limon is definitely one of my favorite restaurants in SF. It opened the door for me to Peruvian cuisine. It started off as the spot I would meet my coworkers for dinner every once in a while. We would order family style and get chicken la brasa, yucca fries, vegetables, rice, ceviche, and sangria ;) We all loved getting together at this spot because it ends up being a decently priced dinner when you are with a group and it's just soooo tasty! I started to hit this spot up when I wanted a nice lunch by myself. Their option to get the chicken la brasa in 1/4 and 1/2 with two sides for about ten dollars is an amazing deal. Aside from price and taste of the food, the huge turn-on for me is the SAUCES. They are the perfect compliment and I can't say enough how much I enjoy them. The only sad thing is that they started charging extra for the sauces, bummer! Overall, great place to bring the family or even grab lunch by yourself.
author: Amanda D.

description:
Tons of reviews, so I'll keep it brief.  Been here three or four times.  Fun atmosphere, but the restaurant is way too crowded and loud for any sort of legitimate conversation.  

I was invited to dinner at Limon for the first time on a first date; I couldn't hear anything the guy was saying the whole night.  I guess the "glass half full" take on this aspect is it can be a great place to take someone you're obliged to do dinner with if your purpose is to enjoy a good meal while tuning them out the whole night.  

Other than the annoyance of waiting in line to be seated when we had a reservation and the noise level, the food is decent - love the ceviche and the sangria - and it's definitely a fun venue in the Mission.
author: Emily C.

description:
Great ceviche!
Great sangria!
Great service!
What more do you want?

Take that special friend and you'll be set.
author: Joe W.

description:
Went to Limon a week or so ago for the first time with a friend.
After reading some of the other reviews on Yelp, I was expecting slow service and a loud restaurant.

Well, our server's name was Alejandro M. and he was awesome! Incredibly attentive and he made great recommendations. We really enjoyed talking to him. The other wait staff were great, our glasses were never empty!

As for the noise...it's a lively restuarant - but my friend and I were able to carry on a conversation easily.

Now on to the good stuff, the food: The snapper ceviche was great!! Loved it!! The beef empanadas were really tasty as were the yuca fries - the sauces served with the empanadas and the fries were interesting and really tasty. 

The lomo saltado was a deconstructed version that was super easy to share and had great flavor.

For Peruvian cuisine, it's a little pricey but the food, the service and the atmosphere makes it worth it. We really enjoyed our meal and can't wait to go back and try some of the other dishes!
author: Eileen F.

description: We took a special guest here for the first time this week and were knocked out. It's a very attractive space, and the hostess and bartender both were warm and efficient. The cocktails were wonderful and different, which is also how I'd describe the food, all of which arrived without waiting long. Everything tasted superb--a huge range of textures, spices, sauces, everything very fresh and pretty. We tried a wide range of small plates. The infamous chicken deserved its accolades but so did the ceviche, the ribs, the crab. We will really enjoy coming here again.
author: Katherine E.

description: This restaurant makes me want to move back here.  It is good for celebration dinners.  I'm getting hungry for the ceviche and the seafood stew just thinking about them.
author: Laura C.

description:
Recently tried this restaurant for the the first time and was very pleased with the decor.  Had a drink at the bar first and found the bartender to not be very attentive or welcoming.  Sat down to dinner and our first waiter was not friendly at all, almost acted surly.  He was replaced with another waiter who was more friendly and recommended our food choices.  However,  as the evening wore on he was not very attentive either.  It was almost like they thought we should be grateful that they were bringing us our food.  The food was good, especially the Seco do Costillas (short ribs) which was to die for.  The ceviche was tasty and so were the empanadas.  The waiter recommended the Chacharron de Pollo which is crispy chicken and one of their specialties but we liked that the least, it was tough and tasted like leather.  One of us had the Churrasco a la Parilla (ribeye)  which was also very good.

Would I go back?  Yes, for the short ribs and perhaps at a later date the wait staff will be happier.
author: Victoria G.

description: The Lomo Saltado is delicious.  I've had various Lomo Saltados before, and I can say this is definitely on my top 5 faves. But I will add that they can add more potato fries to the dish.  I had the ceviche (both vegetarian and non-vegetarian), and it's exquisite--love the citrus.  You must try the oyster shooters.  Nice, chunky, spicy, citrus taste.  I always get an oyster shooter every time I dine at this place.
author: Jose R.

description:
Excellent Service. 
As far as Dessert goes, I could eat a bowlful of the Tres Leches de Coco for breakfast.
Hella good.
author: Karlee D.

description:
my monster suv aka the party bus  brought the bachelorette party here! surprisingly it didn't disappoint with all the hype! sometimes i become a fob (even though i pretty much grew up in the US) or as my hubby would say, i "don kinganize" my words. one example is that i pronounced ceviche with a "k". the list goes on..

8 girls, drinks, pitcher of sangria, and 13 dishes later we needed to be rolled outta here. our waiter was excellent, giving us the right amount of attention and assuming it was our first time, suggested his personal favorites which was too cool! it must have been my first time trying ceviche because i didn't know what to expect. i'm not really into seafood made that way but it was still pretty good. good thing the girls were all kind enough to share so we can all try the different dishes! some of my favorite's were the empanada, arroz con mariscos (similar to a paella), and my chuleton carlitos (pork chops) were so tender and perfectly seasoned! 

we ended the wonderful meal by sharing 2 chocolate bandido's (flourless cake in chocolate sauce w/ ice cream). it was gone in 60 seconds, literally!
author: Jane Y.

description:
Some must haves: empanadas, ceviche, and sangria. I don't know how people manage to fit an entree on top of all that because the ceviche portions are enormous. 

Service could be better. Not a big fan of the servers who try to take away our dishes way before we have a chance to finish them. What's the rush guys? There's nothing wrong with leaving a few empanadas on the table while everyone's eating their main meals. We'll eventually get around to it.
author: Victoria N.

description: I'm glad they were willing to accomodate us since we had our baby with us.  The food was decent... a contemporary play on traditional peruvian food.  The portions are small but filling.  I like the steak but be sure to order sides.  It's mostly tapas.  But the sangria was awesome.  The place is cute and quaint with a space for private parties.  Not what I was expecting.  I heard the South Van Ness location has better food.  Will update if I find my way over there.
author: Mrs. X.

description:
One of my favorite SF restaurants.  I like the ceviche sampler plate - you can get 4 different ceviches.  Also their lomo saltadillo and filet mignon are to die for.

The Peruvian corn is a nice accent, and the purple corn drink is a must-try for that "something different."

Definitely get a reservation if you're going after 8 PM.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
A girl recently took me here as part her plan to move me into the "friend zone". The padded banquettes and the over-sized pitchers of tasty sangria made the landing as smooth as it possibly could be. 

The ceviche, a specialty of the house and a dining highlight, came in an assortment of flavors and it was certainly raw, very much like me sitting there taking the news while trying to maintain an even keel. I'd love to review the main courses, which certainly looked great and I'm sure that they were all "Peruvian" and whatnot, but my taste buds failed to register them as the bites passed through my mouth on the way to my stomach.  I'm certain that it was no fault of the chef's, it's just that my palette had left the building like Elvis on X-lax.

Limon is the best Peruvian food I've ever had, but that's not saying very much for the place!
author: Brian S.

description:
TASTY...

Bambi has gone to Limon several times and it is always satisfying. It does  get crowded even for lunch and I recommend making reservations for dinner otherwise it will be a long wait. 

The interior is very warm and inviting and the service is excellent. Okay I will stop... a few of my friends who hang out at Pink work here and the interior was done by a friend . 

But still it is a wonderful place and a wonderful experience.
author: Teddy d.

description:
I had a great date here, therefore I give it 5 stars. 
This place is so NOT overhyped. The food, the service, and the atmosphere are worth every penny.
author: Geryon R.

description: First lets start with the half chicken with french fries, the chicken was very tasty and moist I can understand why they are known for outstanding chicken. From the first bite to the last very juicy. Now for the business part the french fries were standard frozen type thin fries. We also ordered the Lomito Saltaldo they brought the food out in one of those futuristic oval dishes the looked a tad on the small side. The beef sirloin strips had hardly any flavor other than a hint of smoke from the broiler,the tomatoes onions and french fries were all over cooked and were drowning in heavy soy sauce. Also what happened to the rice? We asked and they don't serve it with rice here. There is a Peruvian restaurant near Santana Row that makes this dish perfectly. If it weren't for the chicken I would have given two stars. One more note you guys need to get rid of those iddy biddy plates, if you give good quality with a decent serving  people will gladly pay even If it cost a little more. After eating one of your house salads I went home and made another?
author: John W.

description: Oh so Peruvian there's nothing like Limon! My favorite is the seafood and ceviche. Perfect blend of tangy and spicy. My mouth waters just thinking about it. Can't wait to go back!
author: Charlene K.

description:
This has got to be one of my all time FAVS!!! Seriously the flavors are explosive, unique and all around AMAZING!!! The atmosphere is a little on the louder side, but still a great date, girls night out or whatever place!!! 

LOVED IT!
author: Rana A.

description:
I had a company dinner here and was very glad we did.

Food is Latino inspired with a California cuisine twist. The food was very good. There new location is less quaint than the last, but the atmosphere is still good. The wait staff was pleasant and helpful and they put together a special desert for us (planned ahead!).

Parking sucks in this area and this place can get crowded, so plan ahead!!
author: JR H.

description:
Stunning and delicious - that is Limon. You might have to coax yourself into going as it's the pricier option among many $5 entree joints, it's totally worth it. I send people over here all the time and only get thanked. 

Try the lomo salteado, it's a genius mix of steak and fries. The fries are sauteed with the steak for just long enough to absorb deliciousness but not so long they get soggy. The ceviche and empanadas are great appetizers. Try a Malbec wine while you're at it because Malbec rocks.
author: C P.

description:
We enjoyed Limon's ceviche quite a bit. The mussels were absolutely delicious--the best dish we had. The truffled mac n' cheese was the second best thing. Sangria was also delicious. Other dishes we had were all good; the only disappointing one was the sauteed mushrooms, which were overdone (down to being worked into a tiny cylinder, tuna tartare style) and a bit salty. Desserts were good, albeit not spectacular.

Service was great, we were seated quickly and the server was friendly. Food and drink came quickly. Prices were high, but similar to other trendy Peruvian restaurants in SF, with better food.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Does Limon serve good food? Yes. Is it a restaurant that serves 100% authentic Peruvian food? No.  I am not from Peru and I've only spent a few weeks traveling from the sea to the Andes but from all the restaurants I visited in the small towns, big cities, and rural villages of Peru, I never once saw truffled mac & cheese or fried calamari on the menu. They got it right with a couple of the seafood & beef dishes. Definitely got it right with some of the ceviche appetizers. The sweet potato, chiles and corn in the Ceviche Limon reminded me of some of my finer moments traveling through this beautiful country. But for a country sometimes referred to as the "land of the purple potato", there were more rice dishes than potato dishes on the menu. 

Why does a restaurant call itself "Peruvian" when it's not. It's fusion. It offers the standard sophisticated fare you see across San Francisco from the Mission to Pacific Heights to the Ferry Building. San Francisco is a tough town. We are spoiled here with many amazing restaurants and cuisines to choose from. I realize to stay in business a chef usually has to keep fried calamari and desserts like creme brulee on the menu no matter what ethnic cuisine they are claiming to prepare and serve. 

You'll enjoy the scene, the cocktails and your dinner but there is nothing unique about Limon. To stay on top of the competition and stay in business - you have to serve to the masses.
author: Muir P.

description: Great food!! Wish they serve bigger plates or else I would rate 5
author: Karen O.

description:
I had a surprisingly great time here. I went with two friends who aren't big drinkers or big eaters, so I thought it'd be me plowing through every plate while they split a salad and looked on in disgust.

Mais non! They ordered heavily, ate heartily and we even ended up getting a carafe of sangria after we blew through our delicious wine. 

The service was great, with a cute little server who took the time to explain things we had questions about and made some great recommendations. The trio of ceviche is really wonderful, with good sized portions, as has been noted before. 

Everything we ate was really good (shout out for the empanadas and the bread pudding), the atmosphere was bustling, the wine list was great and when I found myself eating the fruit out of the sangria glasses I knew I was getting lit. Everything you could ask for in a meal!

I will definitely go back to try the Lomo Saltado.

I was going to go -1 star for the name. Every time I see or hear it, I involuntarily hear Bono screaming "Liiiiiiiiimmmmon" in my head, and nobody needs that. I figure that's a personal problem, though and this good Peruvian restaurant shouldn't have to suffer for it. 5 stars.
author: Leah S.

description:
"Limon, Spanish for yummers!"

Ok, so this is my first review here on yelp, come to think of it, this is my first review ever! So here it goes.

A friend of mine from LA told me to go and check Limon out, so like the good push over that I am I did not hesitate to go as soon as the opportunity presented it self.  But first I had to check it out on the internet, you know, to see what the fuzz is all about. The first thing to caught my eye was that it was a Peruvian cuisine restaurant (what?! I mean, I've never heard about Peruvian food being trendy and none the less tasty, I mean I had the impression that Peru was famous for its Llamas, coca leaf eating Incas, Machu Pichu, meteorological phenomenon "el Nino" and of course who can forget Disney's adorable but sarcastic character emperor Kusco from the Emperor's New Groove).

I went with a very beautiful person to that place (I know that doesn't have any thing to do with the whole write a review thingy, but I just had to let you know, ji!).

We had a reservation at 8pm but got almost 20 minutes early, we thought we would had to wait at the bar, but 40 seconds later we were being seated on our proper table.  The waitress was very amicable, and even though she wasn't Peruvian or South American as a matter of fact, she had ample knowledge about the Latin wine list and menu.

I let my companion choose the wine, she is the expert and I know my weaknesses. For what I saw they had an abundant selection of South American wines and some from California, but like she said, you don't come to a place like this and order California wine and I agreed (proving once more the push over that I am).

We ordered the ceviche de camaron, which where very tasty, it was like if I had prepped them my self on my favorite "restaurante de mariscos" back in Mexico, with the lime and the taste of different types of bottled salsas you find in the Hispanic isle of your local supermarket, perfectly balanced and distributed on the plate. I am guessing they don't use those salsas I am talking about, but if they do, they have the gift of balance. I had to fight several waiters with a fork because they where very eager on taking the plate even though a couple of prawns where still bathing on that tasty tasty pool sauce.

For the main course we ordered the lomo saltodo which was also very good, it comes with fries and onions that are soaked with the beef buttery sauce, I recommend this dish. Also had the pollo latino which was a pan roasted chicken breast that came with macaroni and cheese that left my thinking those people in Kraft, they don't even know... That last dish is one of the restaurants most traditional plates or so the waitress said. I belive, I belive.

My whole dining experience here was great; I have to say Viva Peru! You have changed my whole point of view of what I thought about you in general. Peru has obviously gathered the best of their surrounding countries like, Brazil, Argentina and Chile, but also allowing some American influence to develop these perfect latino-american dishes.
